PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 58 citizens), Senator Campbell (from 12 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned,

PETITION.PARA: (i)are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Ukrainian Independence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: (1)That Ukraine, a nation of 53 million people, one of the ten largest economic entities in the world, with a land area the size of France, and a foundation member of the United Nations declared its independence on August 24, 1991.
(2)That the Ukrainian people have endorsed the declaration of independence by referendum on December 1, 1991.

We Australians and Australians of Ukrainian origin, earnestly request the Australian Parliament to acknowledge the will of the Ukrainian people, as expressed by the Referendum held on the 1st of December 1991, ratifying the declaration of independence of Ukraine by the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet.
We urge the Australian Parliament to:
(a)Formally recognise Ukraine's sovereignty and the Supreme Council as its elected government;
(b)Establish diplomatic representation at the appropriate level;
(c)Institute educational, scientific, cultural and trade links with Ukraine;
(d)Give Ukraine moral, political and economic support in the period of political, social and economic reconstruction that lies ahead.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The curious title of this Bill, which amends a number of Acts, is the Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. It is rather fortunate that the Bill does not presume to name a Prime Minister or the Cabinet because, from the number of Government senators in the chamber this morning, it is fairly obvious that the leadership battle continues, the factions are meeting and the Caucus groups are getting together. I would think that the Prime Minister we have now will not be the Prime Minister we have by the end of the year or early in the New Year. As I say, it is rather fortunate that there are no names mentioned in the title to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Bill, under that broad name, amends a number of Acts. The first is the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981. The amendments will empower the Ombudsman to seek advisory opinions from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal about matters which are being investigated by the internal investigations division of the Australian Federal Police and the Ombudsman. The legislation also amends the Governor-General Act 1974 to omit a provision which, on remarriage, removed the entitlement to an allowance of the surviving spouse of a retired Governor-General.

The Bill further amends the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986 to enable the appointment of an Acting Inspector-General in the event of the absence of the Inspector-General or of a temporary vacancy in that office. It also enables the Inspector-General to require the intelligence and securities agencies to supply copies of annual or periodic reports and, where relevant, ministerial directions or guidelines.

Further, the Bill amends the Ombudsman's Act to empower the Ombudsman to seek advisory opinions from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal about matters which the Ombudsman is investigating and enables the Ombudsman to take further action on a matter which is the subject of a report to parliament. The Bill further ensures that the power of the Ombudsman to obtain documents overrides any prohibition in any other Act.

One aspect of this Bill which concerned the coalition was the proposal to refuse professional privilege as an excuse for denying the Ombudsman access to information. However, upon our investigation, it appears that the Act really only clarifies what has in fact been the existing situation whilst ensuring that information obtained cannot otherwise be used in breach of legal professional privilege.

This Bill also amends the Resource Assessment Act 1989 to exclude the Norfolk Island Government from the definition of a `Commonwealth Authority' in the Act, ensuring that a decision of that Government cannot be reviewed by the Resource Assessment Commission. In line with the coalition's policy to abolish the Resource Assessment Commission, I must say that I agree with the sentiments expressed by the ALP member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, who in Hansard on 5 November 1991, spoke of this move to remove the Norfolk Island Government from the clutches of the Resource Assessment Commission. Mr Campbell said:

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Government to make this the first in a step by step process in which we can exempt everyone else from the Resource Assessment Commission Act.

It is a shame that other members of the Government are not as open-minded or as courageous as Mr Campbell to propose, as he does, a course of action which is in line with the coalition's policy—that is, getting rid of the Resource Assessment Commission.

PARA.TAB: The second group of Bills covered by this legislation deal generally with the Public Service. The Merit Protection Act is amended to enable meetings of the Merit Protection Review Agency to be held either in person or by electronic means. In addition, other amendments allow for the imposition of a fine on those present at proceedings who fail to comply with orders or published orders in defiance of orders.

The Public Service Act is amended to implement the restructuring of the Senior Executive Service into three bands, increasing the flexibility of arrangements by giving greater responsibility for deploying SES officers to heads of departments and agencies, and simplifying procedures for deployment. The Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act is also amended by this Bill to provide that a woman on unpaid maternity leave, which can last for a year, does not become an unattached officer without her written consent. This brings maternity leave into conformity with other forms of unpaid leave in the Public Service.

The amendments to the Public Service Reform Act repeal a section which is unproclaimed and is no longer required. That is a good move which the Liberal and National parties support. It is also a move which the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is very keen on. Bills that have not been proclaimed should be removed from the statute book, and this Bill does that. That is in accordance with Scrutiny of Bills Committee recommendations.

Finally, the Bill amends numerous Acts to allow statutory authorities to determine terms and conditions of employment for their employees without the approval of the Public Service Commission. According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), this is consistent with government policy of devolving responsibility to managers—a policy which the Liberal and National parties have long promoted. I am pleased to see that in his speech the Minister pays at least lip service to that, if not a real intent. At the same time as the Minister said this, he stressed that despite the changes statutory heads will:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . remain covered by the Government's industrial relations and co-ordination arrangements, which ensure the consistent application of the Government's wages and industrial relations policies.
By that statement, the Minister negates the flexibility which the Liberal and National parties believe is essential to good managerial practice.

PARA.TAB: Generally the Opposition has no particular objection to any of the amendments proposed in the Bill; indeed, we support the direction and the thrust of a number of the amendments. However, given the Government's stubborn resistance to genuine industrial relations reform, reinforced in the statement I just mentioned from the Minister's speech, it is appropriate to voice our concerns about the approach being taken by the Government in industrial relations matters generally. I move:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate deplores the Government's failure to acknowledge Commonwealth employees' freedom to associate, and the Government's failure to capture the productivity improvements to be had from enterprise bargaining within the federal Public Service by:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)proscribing compulsory membership of trade unions;
(b)proscribing preference for trade unionists in awards and federal legislation;
(c)abolishing automatic deduction of union dues within Commonwealth departments and authorities; and by

(d)giving the chief executive officers of Commonwealth departments and statutory authorities the same responsibility as their private sector counterparts in deciding the size, composition, deployment, pay and conditions of employees, subject only to a budget constraint".

This amendment highlights the Government's continuing failure to properly address the nagging industrial relations reform issues instead of just simply doing what it is doing—tinkering around the edges. We welcome the changes in the Public Service which will give managers more responsibility in allocating their resources but the Government, unfortunately, has not gone far enough. It does this, I suspect, because it is too scared to take the four decisions in industrial reform which have to be taken. They are the four principles which are central to the coalition's industrial relations policy.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, we believe that there should be freedom for employers and employees to make legally enforceable agreements on their own terms and conditions without the mandatory intervention of unions, employer groups or a tribunal. Secondly, we believe that workers should be free and have the right to choose whether they want to belong to a union or not.

Thirdly, we believe and support an adherence to the principle that, if unions destroy the livelihoods of people or companies, then they should be made to pay for the damage, in the same way all sections of our society are accountable before the law.

Even at this stage there is no guarantee that the Labor Party will not repeal the protection from section 45D against the irresponsible actions of irresponsible unions. If unions do take action irresponsibly which causes damage and causes hurt, harm and financial distress to people or to companies, then they should be made to pay for it. Mr Acting Deputy President, if you did some wrong that caused financial harm to someone, you would be required by the laws of the land to pay for it, to compensate the person who had been hurt. So should the unions. Mr Acting Deputy President, there should not be one law for you, one law for me, and yet another law for the privileged section in our community—the union movement.

There is an indication within the ranks of the Labor Party that they are trying to remove the section 45D protection. Senator Cook abandoned very recently his plan to multiply by five the fines applicable to unions after caving in to ACTU pressure. People on the Labor side of this chamber will remember Senator Cook getting rousing cheers at the Caucus meeting for his courage on the industrial relations reform he was supposed to be implementing.

That afternoon Comrade Kelty called in on Senator Cook and told him that he could not introduce that legislation because it was contrary to the wishes of the ACTU. Brave Senator Cook, as usual, caved in to the wishes and dictates of the bully boys and the union bosses in the ACTU. So this legislation, which he is so proud of, which was reported widely in the papers at the time, did not come in because Senator Cook did not have the intestinal fortitude to stand up for what was right and to stand up to the bully boys in the ACTU.

That simply reinforces my concern and allows me to muse aloud again as to just who is running this Government. It does seem to me that the Minister and the elected Labor Party Caucus come up with some sort of policy which seems to be good and then Comrade Kelty comes along and says, `You can't do that; you are not allowed to introduce it'. Does it not concern you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this sort of thing should happen in an Australian democracy? It is not the Labor Party or the Government running the country; it is a third body, the Australian Council of Trade Unions—the union movement—which is pulling the strings of the puppets in the Government.

Fourthly, we believe there should be a right to join a union, regardless of size, or to form one, with workers not being forced to join a nominated super union which the Government and the Australian Democrats have formed by banning unions with less than 10,000 members. In spite of the fact that the Democrats some years ago opposed that, they were again bought off in a deal with the Government—30 pieces of silver, $2m worth of free advertising or extra staff or whatever—and agreed with the Government on these super unions of 10,000 people.

These are issues which the Government must address. By holding out it is prolonging the inevitable. I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Liberal and National parties will push each and every one of these reforms through this Parliament at some time in the next two years, whenever the then Prime Minister—whoever it might happen to be—is game enough to call an election. Once that is held the result is inevitable, and we will introduce the sort of industrial relations reform that is necessary to get this country going again.

The Labor Party cannot cling to the nostalgic and antiquated days of the old union dominance, of compulsion, of draconian mergers of unions into mega-unions and of further concentrating industrial power in the hands of a few treasured mates in the ACTU. Nothing the Government can do will arrest the increasing irrelevance of the union movement in this country. People, workers, are voting with their feet. They are leaving the unions in droves because the unions are not performing the service they were formed to provide.

Unions have an important role in industrial relations in the 1990s, but the priorities, like those in any organisation to which one chooses to belong, must be to provide members with value for their money. If members are not willing to join a super union which they think is out of touch with what is happening on the shop floor, quite frankly, the union does not deserve to exist. Only those organisations which make it worthwhile to belong, those which provide value in return for union dues rather than leaching money to support the Labor Party without the consent of individual members, will survive, and only they deserve to survive.

My colleague Senator Crane will spend some time talking on industrial relations issues. In the last couple of minutes available to me I want to raise briefly a couple of issues. The next amendments relate to the Public Service Act 1922. They implement the restructuring of the Senior Executive Service into three bands. They increase the flexibility of existing SES arrangements by devolving greater responsibility for deploying SES officers to heads of departments and agencies and simplifying existing procedures for deployment. The Opposition has no objection to any of these amendments. In fact, we have promoted them and we have promoted beyond them.

A number of the changes the Government has made to the Public Service will inject a lot more flexibility into the system. It will be a better system. Unfortunately these and other amendments contained in this Bill, while increasing flexibility, still remain covered by the Government's general industrial relations arrangements, so the increased flexibility is less than it might otherwise have been.

There is no doubt that there has been increased flexibility in the area of industrial relations due to the changes that have been made in recent times. The most recent decision by the Industrial Relations Commission, which was a total turnaround from the position in April, is an improvement. However, it is indeed a very small step towards true workplace bargaining. While the Commission, the unions and employer organisations continue to have a compulsory position set in legislation, we will not get the full benefits and the increases in productivity, profitability and take home pay that a fully flexible system would bring.

It is worth commenting briefly on the situation of the Industrial Relations Commission, the unions and the employers, particularly in light of Senator Coulter's claims relating to our position on democracy. Allowing the system to be more flexible, to be freed up further, is an improvement on democracy, not what Senator Coulter claims. As I have already said, the system now is better than it was 12 months ago and this has been spelt out quite clearly by the shadow Minister, Mr John Howard. However, it still falls a long way short of what could be achieved if the Opposition's policies were adopted.

This Government must stand condemned for continually misrepresenting the Opposition's industrial relations policy. Our position is clear. We will amend the Act to allow employers and employees, if they so choose—and I emphasise those words—to move out of the current system and negotiate their own workplace agreements. In other words, if they choose to stay in, they may stay in; that will be their right. They will have the right to choose whether they wish to belong to a trade union or an employer organisation, or seek the advice of a consultant, or do the negotiating themselves. That is called freedom of choice. It does not mean the demise of the trade union movement or employer organisations. It could well mean that both unions and employer organisations have to lift their game, but that is a different matter. Employers and employees will have the fundamental right to decide who they wish to have represent them—if anyone—or to represent themselves, whether or not they stay within the existing system.

The great myth which is continually peddled by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that we will disband the Industrial Relations Commission is just not true. The other myth, that the Opposition will shut out trade unions, is equally false. We will allow individuals to choose whether they wish to belong to a trade union. In other words, we will bring an end to closed shops or what is commonly known as `no ticket, no job'. One thing that must be clearly understood is that, as well as the right to associate and form an association or organisation or a union, there must also be the right in a free society not to associate. In other words, free men and women in this country should not be forced, by the effect of a loaded, unfair law, to deal through a body for which they have no time or respect.

It is only a matter of time before our policy is introduced. People in the workplace will demand it. The employers will demand it. In fact, it is already happening in many workplaces. I would like to highlight a case in Western Australia where a relatively small operation employed 43 people. As a result of the recession and decisions that were made by the Arbitration Commission, the management of that business had no choice but to negotiate with its employees and put off approximately 20 per cent of them—eight of the 43—and reduce its staff to 35.

They met and discussed the whole issue. In the final analysis—and this has not hit the headlines, so I am not naming the people involved—they decided to take pay cuts ranging from 10 per cent to 15 per cent and keep their jobs. There was a 15 per cent cut at the highest level of employment and for management, and a 10 per cent cut for the lowest paid. That was a joint agreement. When management was approached by the union, it said to the union, `You can now nominate those eight people who are going to lose their jobs'. The union did not want to know about it.

What I am saying about our policy position is that it is happening now. That has not disadvantaged anyone in the sense of being able to keep their jobs. It has not disadvantaged the company in the sense that it restricted its operations. It has meant that that company is now in a position to keep all those people in employment, to stay in business and, when the recovery comes—which it surely will when we get into government—that company will be in a position to expand and continue to grow.

The other point I want to make about our industrial relations policy versus the Government's position, albeit one that has improved from what it was 12 months ago, is the position that exists at Kambalda in Western Australia. It is on the public record that, in the initial negotiations between Western Mining and its employees, they were quite happy and prepared to reach an agreement to shift to full rostered working seven days a week. It was only when the union got involved that those arrangements fell over. I should also add the State Government because the Deputy Premier of Western Australia is also guilty of letting that arrangement fall over. The impact is that about 100 jobs have been lost and the investment of $106m has gone.

I would have liked to address further points on industrial relations, but I conclude by saying that there is no doubt that the position we have adopted will happen. It will happen because it is necessary for Australia. It is totally irrelevant for Senator Coulter to compare the situation in Australia with that in Sweden, just as it would be irrelevant for the Swedes to compare their situation with the Australian situation.

We will be moving to allow the system to be freed up. We will be giving freedom of choice to individuals as to whether they stay in the existing system or whether they move out and negotiate. We will give them the freedom of choice as to whether they utilise the services of an employer organisation or a union to negotiate for them, or whether they choose to do it themselves. It will, in fact, improve the position of democracy in industrial relations in this country. It will lead to increases in productivity, it will lead to more profitability of companies and it will lead to greater take-home pay for the individuals involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —At some stage I would like to speak at length on the subject matter of the amendment to the Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, but on this occasion I will speak shortly because of the time constraints that are upon us to get through a whole bunch of legislation before Christmas. If somebody can point out to me where there is compulsory membership of trade unions in the Public Service, then I will support the amendment because I, together with I believe an overwhelming number of members of trade unions and of trade unions themselves, am against compulsory membership.

PARA.TAB: I have fought, both as an official of an individual union registered under the Industrial Relations Act and as Secretary-General of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council in my previous existence, for the rights of a person who has a genuine conscientious objection to becoming a member of a trade union not to do so. I have stood up for this in debate and arguments, and eventually I have made sure that in areas for which I am responsible this is made known by organisers to persons who are likely to be invited to join trade unions. TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Prime Minister and Cabinet Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, a portfolio Bill from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. This Bill amends several Acts under the aegis of that Department and, as Minister assisting the Prime Minister on Public Service matters, it comes to me to carry this legislation through the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The Acts that are amended by this Bill are the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, the Governor-General Act 1974, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986, the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973, the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984, the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Public Service Act 1922, the Public Service Reform Act 1984, the statutory authority legislation and the Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989.

While all of those are quite significant and important Acts of this Parliament, the amendments that are being made can be characterised fairly as important and significant amendments in their own right but not substantial changes to the fundamentals of any of those Acts.

The global effect of these amendments is to make some changes within the application of those Acts to bring them up to date with standards that need to be applied in the Public Service and/or to make some other operational changes to those Acts. While this Bill has a comprehensive scope in terms of the number of Acts that it deals with, it is not hugely significant legislation; it is more catching-up-and-improving legislation, gardening legislation to remove the weeds, improve the growth and let the existing legislation get on with itself.

The Opposition has indicated that it does not oppose any of these amendments. The Australian Democrats have expressed support for the legislation more positively than the Opposition. The Opposition indicated its position by saying that it does not oppose this Bill, which I guess means that it will vote for it; the Democrats said that they support the Bill, which clearly means that they will vote for it.

An amendment to this Bill, moved at the second reading stage by Senator Macdonald on behalf of the Opposition, has occupied the time of this chamber. This is in similar terms to an amendment moved in the House of Representatives by the shadow Minister for industrial relations, Mr Howard, which was defeated. It is an amendment that refers to industrial relations. While industrial relations is not directly dealt with in any of these amendments, some of the amendments have an effect of improving the industrial relations climate in the Public Service, so the Opposition has taken this opportunity to stage a debate of very indifferent quality on industrial relations. Others may say that Opposition senators took the opportunity to simply parade their prejudices about industrial relations to make some fairly obscure points. Therefore, I think there is an obligation on me, in replying to this debate, to deal, albeit briefly, with some of the matters put by the Opposition.

One cannot characterise a debate on industrial relations simply in terms of what the Opposition has tried to do—that is, engage purely, simply, blatantly and nakedly in a union-bashing exercise. Industrial relations is more than that, and that is not a serious debate under the industrial relations heading. I will deal with the Opposition's narrow and prejudicial view of this field from the points it has raised. The starting point is obviously the Opposition's own amendment, which is instructive. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but the Senate deplores the Government's failure to acknowledge Commonwealth employees' freedom to associate. . .

The words `freedom to associate' have a precise and defined legal meaning in the field of industrial relations. Here it is not used in its precise or defined meaning; it is used as a public relations phrase to make it appear that something is when in fact something is not.

PARA.TAB: The defined legal meaning of `freedom of association' is the right of individuals to freely associate in trade unions. Convention 87, the Convention on the Freedom of Association, of the International Labour Organisation, the United Nations industrial relations agency, sets minimum labour standards for the world. The meaning of `freedom of association' is thereby defined within the United Nations framework for our consumption. It is not what the Opposition is now talking about. It is a right of trade unions to exist and a right of individual workers to join them. It is not, as the Opposition is proposing in this amendment, that trade unions should be dismantled and divided and that the right of so-called independent contracts undermine a recognised system of awards that prescribes minimum rates of pay. The use of language in the first part of the Opposition's amendment illustrates an attempt to make something appear different from that which it is with no respect for legal meaning. The amendment continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and the Government's failure to capture the productivity improvements to be had from enterprise bargaining within the federal Public Service by:
(a)proscribing compulsory membership of trade unions;

From the Opposition's amendment, the casual observer would comprehend that there is compulsory membership of trade unions in the Australian Public Service. That is the implication, but there is not. The Commonwealth does not insist on members of the Australian Public Service being members of trade unions. That is not clear from this amendment, which sets up a belief and demolishes it as if it were true and as if this amendment, if it were carried, would do something. All it would do is support exactly what happens. There is no compulsory membership of trade unions forced on employees of the Commonwealth Public Service by the Government.

PARA.TAB: The Government insists that the principle of merit govern employment within the Australian Public Service, including the rights of transfer and promotion for its own work force, which is extensive and numerous in this country. It is for individuals within the Australian Public Service to decide for themselves whether to join a union. Their applications for employment, transfer or promotion will be dealt with not on the basis of whether they are a member of a union but on the basis of the merits of their particular case.

This was no better or more clearly set out than in the second reading speech on the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill in 1986, when the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Public Service Matters said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill strengthens and extends the existing prohibition on patronage, favouritism and discrimination. Section 33 of the Act will state categorically that powers are to be exercised without patronage, favouritism or discrimination. The disciplinary provisions will be amended to make express reference to the fact that patronage, favouritism or discrimination amount to misconduct and render officers liable to disciplinary action.

As a consequence of the passage of that Bill, principles were brought into play which, in effect, provide that all eligible persons must have a reasonable opportunity to apply for any position; appointment must be made on the basis of an assessment of the relative suitability of the applicants; powers in relation to appointment, transfer or promotion shall be exercised without patronage or favouritism; discrimination is precluded on the grounds of political affiliation, race, colour, ethnic origin, social origin, religion, sex, sexual preference, marital status, pregnancy, age or physical or mental disability; and discrimination that is unlawful under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 or the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, or any other unjustified discrimination.

PARA.TAB: So, under the auspices of this Government, the merit principle sits as the foundation stone for the activities of public servants in this country. For the Opposition to propose and infer in its amendment that that is not the case does not reflect on us but reflects very sadly on the Opposition's competence or efforts to try to gull the Australian community into believing that something other than what is the case operates in these circumstances.

The most significant commentary that came through the second reading contributions of a number of senators was the point that the Public Service needs to be made more flexible to take advantage of the options for enterprise negotiations. These remarks were made by Senator Macdonald and echoed, in his own way, by Senator Crane. Certainly Senator Harradine made some very pertinent observations about the direction of policy implementation, based on the remarks of Senators Macdonald and Crane. I think the remarks by Senator Harradine in this debate are apposite.

The background that I will now give will disprove essentially the contention made by the Opposition, assuage to some extent, although not completely, the concerns voiced by Senator Harradine and perhaps explain to the community what is in fact the case. Once again, if one looks at what is, rather than what is alleged, one can see that what is, in fact, is a balanced and responsible approach by a government managing its public sector with a great deal of success—success not only on the basis of the quality of the services provided but also on the basis of the economic cost of those services and the job satisfaction of the public servants involved in providing those services.

The April national wage case resulted in a decision by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to award a 2.5 per cent wage increase, among other things, upon application by unions. As a result of that wage case, the Government entered into negotiations with public sector unions for accord mark VI changes and reached an agreement that the basis for wage improvements over the 2.5 per cent would be productivity changes. That raised squarely and centre stage: how then do we in a public service calculate what is the level of productivity change, what are the factors that cause it, and how best are the rewards that are generated by it to be distributed to those who have had a hand in doing so?

Productivity is not a matter of people simply working harder. It is also a matter of what capital investment has been made in the Public Service, particularly in the computerisation of services, in order to provide more and efficient services. It is a matter of capital investment as well as work practices. Indeed, if one is to examine both elements, the capital investment one is by far and away the most significant.

As a result of the agreements reached with the public sector unions and the commitment to a form of productivity bargaining in the public sector, the Government set up a committee of senior public servants, all of them Secretaries or heads of their own departments or agencies, chaired by the Secretary of my Department, the Department of Industrial Relations. The membership of the committee includes the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the head of the Department of Finance, the head of the Department of the Treasury and a number of other departmental heads, including the head of the Department of Social Security. The question of, `How can you generate productivity measurements as a basis for productivity wage negotiations?', has been under examination by this committee. It has produced an interim report which is publicly available for discussion and debate.

I might say that no Opposition spokesperson has made any contribution at all in response to the report that has been published on this subject—certainly not the shadow spokesman, Mr Howard, who is very vociferous in his comments elsewhere. But having been confronted with an absolute report dealing with the subjects that he struts the public stage pontificating about, has he responded? No, of course he has not.

In addition to that, the Government has appointed a group of professors of economics and industrial relations from the University of Newcastle, the University of New South Wales and the University of Cambridge in Great Britain to provide a second report. This is, if you like, a report from outside the Public Service; a report from people with an objective point of view and with an academic background which can be held against the report of the senior bureaucrats. On the basis of that, there can be more informed government decision making. Those professors are Professor Barry Hughes, a professor of economics at the University of Newcastle; Professor John Niland, Dean of the Faculty of Commerce and Economics at the University of New South Wales; and Professor Willie Brown, a professor of industrial relations at Cambridge University in the United Kingdom. Their report has been lodged in the last few days. The Cabinet will take the recommendations of both the bureaucrats and the professors and consider how, in the light of those reports, productivity matters can be dealt with.

I contrast a procedure as considered as that, as informed as that and as involved as that, with the simple assertion that, `We should do something; we should do something to just simply decentralise'. It is not a matter of just making assertions like that; it is a matter of government taking responsibility.

There are very serious questions involved here and Senator Harradine referred to some of them. Let me cite one of those questions. The Australian Public Service is based on the model of the public service in Britain. It is a public service with a tradition of fearless advice, irrespective of who is in government. It is a public service with salary scales and promotional levels similar right across the board, irrespective of which department one is employed in.

The Opposition's amendment proposes that all of the agencies and departments be broken up and the career and traditional nature of the Public Service be changed to one in which each department or agency is an individual enterprise, each secretary is a chief executive and each employee in that department is simply a worker to be treated under the terms and conditions of whatever is the objective of that department.

The first problem with that is that it destroys the fundamental nature of the Public Service as it stands now and changes the levels of remuneration most likely between agencies or departments—so promotion across the Public Service is set aside. The second problem with that is that some sections of the Public Service do have scope for high productivity increase. I refer here to the service provider sections such as the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the CES.

Areas of the Public Service that provide services to the community—such as DSS, the Tax Office and CES—can find ways within their so-called enterprise to be more productive, and that is a good thing if they can. But what about the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, for example—the Department which is the subject of the legislation that is now before us—which essentially offers policy advice? What about the Department of the Treasury which is essentially monitoring international economic conditions, Australian economic conditions, and advising on policy related to those conditions?

I see that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Michael Tate, is in the chamber. He is the Minister with responsibility for the Attorney-General's Department, where legal opinions are obtained. How do we require lawyers to put out more legal opinions in a day for the same amount of money in order to create productivity? I note for the record that Senator Harradine is shaking his head at this point, as if to indicate that we cannot. If that is his indication, I agree with him. How then, in the service providing departments where there is scope for some productivity change, do we match that with the intellectual activity of advice giving in the advice providing departments? That is, at core, one of the central dilemmas of this situation. The Opposition's motion does not address that issue at all. It simply says that we should go down its route, irrespective of the evidence, complications or whatever.

In the last few minutes of the time I wish to spend on this subject, I turn to what is, in essence, the absolute and fundamental divide between the conservative side of politics in this country and the non-conservative side of politics. On the non-conservative side, I include, in that wide embrace, the Australian Democrats, who have spoken on this Bill with some force. The basic difference that divides the Opposition and the Government—or the conservatives and the non-conservatives—is that the Government is committed to a form of industrial relations which promotes cooperation in the Australian workplace and the Opposition is committed to a form of industrial relations which promotes conflict. There can be no more neatly defined difference: it is a choice between cooperation and conflict.

We wish to work with the institutions that exist in the field of industrial relations for the purpose of achieving reform. The Opposition wishes to confront those institutions, undermine them or weaken them for the purpose of achieving a computer-driven policy objective. We recognise and give responsibility to trade unions to play their role along with the other institutions in Australian society; whereas the Opposition wishes to exclude, isolate, attack and scapegoat trade unions as though they were the absolute evil of society.

In fundamental terms, that is the great divide. I believe Australians will support the cooperative approach. Indeed, if results account for anything, in the period of the Hawke Government compared with the period of the Fraser Government, industrial disputes in this country have reduced by some 60 per cent. That is one of the best examples of the difference between the Fraser Government's form and our form; it is an example of greater cooperation. Because we have accentuated the cooperative model, we now find that increasingly in Australian industry employees and employers are getting together. The old boss-worker divide—which is a feature of the conflict model—no longer applies with the same degree of force as it did in the past.

We find employers and workers getting together to set jointly the productive targets for their companies, working out how best to share fairly the rewards of success between them, and then going about creating a more productive company atmosphere. That is true of a whole range of companies—many of them leading companies in this country. That is a reason why we are now on the threshold of a surge in productivity in Australia, which has been brought about by the achievements of award restructuring, award modernisation, career pathing for workers in industry and so on.

So, in essence, we seek a means of empowering individuals in the workplace, through their legitimately recognised organisations, to respect and have regard for the ideas that they can put forward. We respect their role; we do not simply see them as units of production to be commanded and controlled and to have to be forced into a situation of one against the bureaucracy, as though one individual negotiating with the bureaucracy of a company or the bureaucracy of a government is a fair bargaining basis. That is the difference and the fundamental divide. That is, essentially, why I do not accept the Opposition's view.

Senator Crane and Senator Macdonald insisted upon making a couple of points about industrial relations. The first point Senator Macdonald made—which is a foundational concept of the Opposition—involved the freedom of employers and employees to enter into direct contracts. That sounds lovely, benign and reasonable. But that is not lovely, it is not benign and it is unreasonable. It is a glib phrase, and, in its glibness, it means that the umpire—in this case the Industrial Relations Commission—whose job it is to ensure fair play and reasonable conduct in industrial relations, is taken out of the equation. So the players on the field have no umpire to guarantee that the parties play by the rules and that they are fair and reasonable.

It also means that the awards in this country —which are awards of the Commission, determined by the umpire in this case, and which, by and large, set minimum standards for industry sectors—are to be subverted and undermined. The effect of not being able to contract out of an award is fundamental, but that is to be undermined. So minimum protections are to be taken away; minimum protections which guarantee fair labour standards are to be removed. The umpire goes, the minimum standards go and, on that basis, we are then left with only the union structure in this country.

If one turns to page 2 of the Australian Financial Review of last Thursday, one can see in the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) that it is his intention to destroy those organisations. That is a transitional cost of the achievement of the consumption tax package that he has put forward. The umpire goes, the minimum protections go and the trade unions are destroyed. The Opposition then achieves the objective of freedom for employers and employees to enter into direct contracts. If that is not a recipe for exploitation, then one has never been put forward in the history of this country.

I have dealt with the second of the three points made by Senator Macdonald: the freedom to choose to belong or not to belong to a union, which is fundamental to what applies in the Commonwealth Public Service. I conclude by dealing with the third point: that unions should be brought within the bounds of the law. In many respects, this is the greatest insult to the Australian mind because unions operate within the bounds of law. If they do not they can be dealt with under that law.

Unions, by and large, are registered with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The right of that registration confers benefits and privileges, but obligations and responsibilities as well. One ought to look to see what those obligations and responsibilities are. They are obligations about free and democratic elections to ensure that the leadership of those organisations is elected properly; they are obligations about reporting the financial concerns of unions to ensure that the funds are not mismanaged; and they are obligations about how one should participate in the industrial process.

But when the Opposition talks about the law, it talks about contract law or criminal law. It does not recognise that in this country, as in every civilised and developed country in the world, there are different provinces of law. Criminal law is a particular province, company law is a particular province, family law is a particular province, administrative law is a particular province, and so is industrial law. Industrial law is on the statute books of this country perforce of a provision in the Constitution which enables it to be put there.

The Opposition wants to bring the common law into the province of industrial law and set aside the constitutional right of governments in this country to write law, under the Constitution, in the field of industrial relations. That is what those opposite are talking about. It is vastly different from this innocent, so-called reasonable proposition about the force of the common law.

Reasonable labour standards in the world—as set down by the United Nations agency, the ILO; the Australian Constitution; and statute law in industrial relations—require the observance of those laws and the respect for minimum standards. By setting aside that law, the Opposition wishes to undermine those minimum standards and drive down wages in Australia, as though making this country a low wage country and turning us into the Taiwan of the South Pacific is somehow or other a recipe for economic reform. I commend the Bill to the Senate.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1991 makes four amendments in relation to the National Crime Authority Act 1984. First, new section 29A provides that, where a member of the NCA summons a witness to give oral evidence or issues a notice requiring the production of documents, the summons or notice may include a notation prohibiting the disclosure of certain information.

PARA.TAB: New section 29B provides for penalties for disclosure under circumstances where disclosure may be allowed, for example, in seeking legal advice. This amendment is proposed because it has happened in the past that persons or institutions served with a summons or notice have disclosed the existence of that summons or notice and information relating to the NCA's investigations. There are attendant risks of jeopardising investigations and damaging reputations.

The second amendment proposed in this Bill is to section 31, which provides for a member of the NCA to apply to a court to obtain a warrant of apprehension where a person has or is likely to abscond or is otherwise likely to attempt to evade service of a summons. It does not currently provide for a warrant application in relation to a person who fails or refuses to appear in response to a summons. The amendment proposed corrects that anomaly.

Thirdly, section 50 of the NCA Act is amended to allow the Chairman of the NCA, instead of the Attorney-General, to appoint counsel to assist the Authority. The Opposition is of the view that this is reasonable since it would normally be the Chairman who is in the best position to assess the need to appoint counsel.

Fourthly, pursuant to amendments to section 59, the NCA will be authorised to provide reports at the request of a State or Territory Minister, who is a member of the NCA's inter-governmental committee, to that Minister about the NCA's investigations within that jurisdiction.

The coalition does not oppose these amendments, although we do have some concerns about those relating to non-disclosure notation. Under the proposed new section 29A, a member of the NCA will be able to exercise a discretion to include in a summons or notice a notation prohibiting the disclosure of certain information where the failure to do so might prejudice a person's reputation or safety, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence or the effectiveness of an investigation, or might otherwise be contrary to public interest.

The Opposition basically agrees with this proposal and the underlying aim, which is to make the NCA more open and accountable. However, I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment on behalf of the Opposition with the intention of strengthening this provision. It is our view that the NCA should further be obliged to include a non-disclosure notation where failure to do so would reasonably be expected to prejudice the safety or reputation of the person, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence or the effectiveness of an investigation.

I also foreshadow a further amendment to ensure that, where a member of the NCA includes in a summons or notice a non-disclosure notation, he must also provide a written statement setting out the rights and obligations that the person has under proposed section 29B, which sets out the penalties for disclosure and the circumstances in which disclosure may be allowed.

I should mention that the amendments I will be moving in the committee stage differ in some respects from those that were moved by my colleague in the other chamber, Mr Wilson, who was then the acting shadow Attorney-General. The differences are a result of discussions between the coalition and the Government. I understand that the amendments in their redrafted form are now acceptable to the Government. In the committee stage I will move those amendments, but otherwise we support the second reading of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is discussing the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1991. The main provisions are contained in clause 2 and detail amendments to sections 28 and 29. Proposed section 29A will allow a member of the NCA issuing a summons on notice under sections 28 and 29 to include a notification that disclosure of the information in the document is prohibited except in the circumstances, if any, listed in the notification. The prohibition is to be included only if the member is satisfied that it is necessary to prevent prejudice to the safety or reputation of a person, a fair trial or the effectiveness of an investigation, or a situation contrary to the public interest. The notification will cease to be in force if the investigation is completed and either the evidence has been given or no evidence has been obtained.

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 29B will make it an offence to breach a section 29A prohibition by the recipient. Disclosure will be allowed only where it is in accordance with the circumstances specified in the notice—that is, made to a legal practitioner to gain advice; made to officers of a company, if necessary, to allow the company to comply; made by a legal practitioner in accordance with the professional duty to his client; or to obtain agreement to disclose a privileged communication. Where the information has been disclosed to an officer of a company that person may subsequently disclose the information to another officer to ensure compliance or to a legal practitioner to obtain advice. Legal practitioners may also subsequently disclose the information to give assistance in accordance with the principal Act.

Section 30 of the principal Act provides that people are guilty of an offence if they fail to attend a hearing when they have been summonsed. Clause 3 of this Bill will amend section 31 of the principal Act, which deals with arrest powers to enable the Authority to apply to a court for a warrant for the arrest of people who have committed such an offence or who are not likely to attend a hearing.

Thirdly, clause 4 of the Bill will amend section 50 of the Act to provide that the Chairman of the Authority, instead of the Attorney-General, may appoint counsel to assist the Authority. I submit that the delegation of power brought about by clause 4 is an appropriate and reasonable one. The need to appoint legal counsel to assist the Authority is a matter which the Chairman is in the best position to assess.

Clause 5 of the Bill will amend section 59 of the principal Act to provide that, where a State Minister on the intergovernmental committee requests specific information on the exercise of the NCA's general powers within the Minister's jurisdiction, the NCA must comply with the request. Such requests currently go through the Commonwealth Minister and similar provisions exist in respect of special investigations.

The Australian Democrats support the thrust of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill. We will also support the Opposition amendments which seek to strengthen it and to put a stronger obligation on the members of the NCA to issue such a notice when certain conditions are met.

I take this opportunity to express appreciation for the work done by Mr Justice Phillips, who is the Chairman of the NCA. He is leaving to be appointed as Chief Justice of Victoria. If I may express my opinion with the utmost respect, I am sure that he will grace that office as much as he has graced the office of Chairman of the NCA. He has introduced new directions which have been much needed and much appreciated. This has moved the Authority towards greater openness and accountability. It has provided for greater sharing of crime intelligence with other law enforcement agencies and lead to a greater level of cooperation with those agencies and to a much more focused use of the quite extraordinary powers that the NCA has and which this Bill is dealing with today.

I also wish to take the opportunity to comment briefly on the evaluation report of the National Crime Authority which has been tabled by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority. Given the time constraints that are now upon the Senate, I do not expect that the report will be debated this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are wrong.

—I hope I am wrong, too. However, I wish to put on record briefly that I am in general agreement with the conclusions of the majority report and, in particular, the provisions which seek to make it clear that the Committee must have greater access to information to be able to carry out its statutory duty to supervise the NCA. I note that the Committee has seen fit—I am grateful for that—to adopt the exemptions which are included in my private member's Bill which place a duty of confidentiality on members of the Committee. The exemptions are that Committee members may not disclose information which would, firstly, identify persons in a manner which would be prejudicial to the safety or legal rights of those persons; secondly, prejudice legal proceedings whether those proceedings have commenced; and, thirdly, disclose the operational methods of the Authority in a manner prejudicial to the operations of the Authority.

PARA.TAB: I part company with the majority report where it is not prepared to accept, in the event of a dispute between the NCA and the Committee, that the Attorney-General, the Minister of the day, be empowered to adjudicate such a dispute. I have proposed that it should be a judge of the Federal Court of Australia not sitting as a judge of the court. I believe this removes the political aspect that should not be present in such an adjudication.

I also wish to put on record that the second option in dealing with the flow of information to the Committee is entirely unacceptable. The majority report suggests that there could be a second option, if the Government so chooses; namely, that the criteria which are currently being used to define the information which the Committee members may not disclose should be used to define which information should not even reach the Committee. Such a provision would stymie the Committee's efforts to supervise the Authority which is its statutory duty, and would be totally unacceptable. I trust that in due course the Government will see fit to ensure that the Parliamentary Committee which was established to deal with individual complaints as well as the general operations of the National Crime Authority is given the powers it needs to carry out its duties competently and efficiently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express support for the general principles of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1991. Clause 2 of the Bill inserts proposed new sections 29A and 29B. Where the Authority summonses witnesses to give oral evidence or issues a notice requiring the production of documents, a member of the Authority will be given discretionary powers to include in a summons or a notice a notation prohibiting disclosure of certain information.

PARA.TAB: That is done for two reasons: firstly, to prevent what is described as a tip off; that is, to prevent disclosure to someone who may well be under investigation from having access to that knowledge and, therefore, perhaps destroying the evidence or so arranging his affairs as to prevent a proper and exhaustive investigation, and also in the event that it was likely to prejudice the safety or reputation of a person or `the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence', as the amendment says. To the extent that the proposition goes that far, we agree.

The second amendment is to clause 3 of the Bill, which amends section 31 of the National Crime Authority Act to enable the Authority to apply to a court to obtain a warrant for the arrest of a person who, having been served with a summons, fails or refuses to appear at a hearing conducted by the Authority. For reasons which are not immediately apparent to me, the Act is limited to the extent that the Authority can presently have a recalcitrant witness either gaoled or fined. That in no way goes towards attaining the information that the Authority would want. This amendment requires by summons the appearance of a reluctant witness at a hearing.

Thirdly, clause 4 of the Bill amends section 50 of the Act to provide that the Chairman of the Authority, rather than the Attorney-General, as presently applies, appoint counsel to assist the Authority. Everybody would agree that the person best able to judge whether counsel is required—to the extent that counsel is required, and what counsel is required—is the Chairman of the Authority and not the Attorney-General. Of course, that amendment also has our support.

Finally, clause 5 of the Bill amends section 59 of the Act which sets out the obligations of the Authority in respect of the reporting of its activities. Presently, for general investigations the reporting of the Authority goes via this complicated, convoluted route to the Federal Attorney-General, to the Inter-Governmental Committee and then to the various State authorities. As I understand it, it is proposed that the same course be taken for general inquiries as is taken for special investigations; that is, they go directly to the various States. Presumably, that will provide for a more effective flow of information and also for greater monitoring of the Authority.

We support the thrust of the Bill; however, we have two amendments of our own to which, no doubt, Senator Hill referred. The first is that it makes it an obligation for the Authority to place a prohibition on information in the circumstances set out in the Bill. It may well be that certain circumstances will arise in which it is not necessarily in the interests of the Authority to put a prohibition on disclosure of the serving of the summons and the demand for information. It is our view that it should be mandatory, compulsory and obligatory for the Authority to place the prohibition. We also propose that a notation be accompanied by a written statement setting out the reasons and the rights of the person receiving the summons.

Mr Acting Deputy President, like Senator Spindler, I will take this opportunity to touch on some matters which go to the heart of the National Crime Authority Act and also the very elegant report that was prepared by the Authority, entitled Who is to Guard the Guards: An Evaluation of the National Crime Authority.

I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) what the Government's attitude to the secrecy provisions now is, because these matters of concern have been before the Government for some time. Justice Phillips himself has set down his preferred options for disclosure within the confines of section 51. Senator Spindler has introduced a private member's Bill; I have also introduced a private member's Bill.There are some recommendations in the report as to how they can be dealt with, because the present situation is most unsatisfactory.

I might say, by way of qualification, that having the Attorney-General adjudicate is not my preferred option because it simply means that it will be capable of being political because the Attorney-General, of course, is a political animal. There will also be a temptation for the Attorney-General to take the soft option and agree with the National Crime Authority in the event that there is a dispute between the Authority and the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

I did not detect a ground swell of support for Senator Spindler's proposal within our ranks, which was to have a sitting member of the Federal Court adjudicate on disputes. I am essentially of the view that the Parliament cannot have non-parliamentarians adjudicating in those matters, so my own preferred option ultimately was that as the Committee, like all committees, will be thoroughly responsible and accountable to the public, to the Parliament and to its peers, there should be a process where the Committee could be required to seek written advice from a retired member of the Federal Court, that advice to be tabled in the event that it is ignored by the Committee.

I would have thought that would be a fairly sobering sanction on any member of the Committee who sought disclosure of any information. It is not the disclosure of operational matters or any matters from the NCA to the Committee that are of concern, it is the next point; it is the disclosure of that information advertently or inadvertently, either properly or improperly, through reports to the Parliament or elsewhere, that is of concern. If a member of the Committee, or the Committee as a whole, were of a mind to disclose information in a report, if there had been a recommendation from a retired judge suggesting that the report ought not be made available, I would have thought that would be a sanction.

The Minister will be mindful of the fact that there has been a tortuous route taken by this Government with respect to secrecy provisions generally. We have had nonsense opinions from the Solicitor-General and from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) which argue that general secrecy provisions prevail—prevail, that is, in the face of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. The reason we have the Parliamentary Privileges Act, almost as a declaratory piece of legislation, is to put to rest the nonsense arguments that in some way those secrecy provisions placed a prohibition on members of parliament.

We have received a written opinion in respect of the Australian Sports Drug Agency which advised the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that it is unable to disclose the names of athletes who have given a positive sample. I understand that opinion has now been reversed, although the confidential advice to the officers is, `Don't tell unless you have to'. Secondly, we received an opinion in respect of the Health Act, and that opinion has now been reversed. It had arrived at the same conclusion from a different route. Thirdly, we have had a different opinion in respect of the National Crime Authority. These opinions are all nonsense.

During the debate on the Estimates in the Committee of the Whole I asked what the final position was in respect of the Sports Drug Agency. I was told by the Minister on duty, Senator Richardson, that the opinion provided by the Attorney-General to the Department in itself was now under review and that it should not be taken as the final word. I would ask the Minister what the Government's position is in respect of secrecy provisions because, frankly, it makes a nonsense of the Committee. The Government itself has referred to the consequences, the effectiveness and the relevance of the Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who contributed to this debate on the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1991. It is an important Bill. Although its provisions perhaps do not go to the heart of the operations of the Authority, it does mark yet another occasion on which this Parliament, and in particular this Senate, has considered the state of the National Crime Authority in Australian society. It certainly gives me an opportunity to join with members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in saying that, since Mr Justice Phillips was appointed on 14 August last year, he has transformed not only the operations of the National Crime Authority but also its relationships with both this Parliament—which, of course, is its creator—and those other law enforcement agencies throughout Australia with whom he has adopted a much more cooperative stance than was the case with his predecessors.
—And much more sensible.

—I believe it is more sensible because it will help achieve the objective of the Authority, which is to ensure that within the Australian law enforcement system there is a repository of those extraordinary powers which are sometimes required in order to investigate organised criminal activity in Australia, and yet it should be done in a way which recognises that other agencies—whether State police forces, other commissions of a like kind in the States, or arms of other agencies such as Customs—all have their part to play in tackling the phenomenon of organised crime in Australian society.

PARA.TAB: Justice Phillips has attempted to work in a very practical and harmonious fashion with those agencies which, by the way, have themselves reached a new stage in maturity which allows that partnership to be forged. In fairness to the first Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Justice Stewart, it must be said that at the time when he assumed office there were well-founded misgivings about the capacity, in simple competence terms, and certainly the probity of even the highest levels of some of the other law enforcement agencies which had been operating in Australia for many years without any significant impact on organised criminal activity in some jurisdictions.

I believe that stage has now been passed in Australian society, thank goodness, and that it is now possible for the National Crime Authority to work more confidently with the State police forces and other law enforcement agencies around Australia. The new role of the National Crime Authority, as a coordinator and as a repository of those extraordinary powers which need to be vested somewhere—under democratic control of this Parliament—in the investigation of alleged criminal activity, is certainly proving to be much more relevant and successful.

One thinks, for example, of the allegations that are made from time to time about Italian elements in organised criminal activity in Australia. Late last year there was a conference held which brought together various personnel from Australia and even overseas who could make a very well-informed contribution to the intelligence gathering within Australia of criminal activity with that colouring. On the occasion of the reception being held in association with that conference, I recall with great pleasure meeting Judge Falcone from Italy, who has led the fight against the Mafia in Sicily. I had the honour of meeting him again in Rome some four or five weeks ago. He has taken a very real interest in helping to alert Australian law enforcement authorities on matters of mutual interest in the fight against criminal activity. He is a very brave man indeed. It is that sort of ability demonstrated by Mr Justice Phillips in the newly revamped National Crime Authority, and which brought to bear the best advice and intelligence not only from within Australia but also from overseas in tackling organised crime, which augurs well for the future of the Authority.

A few areas of the Bill require strengthening. It has been found, for example, that some recipients of a summons or notice from the National Crime Authority such as financial institutions were in a quandary. They felt that they had very real obligations to their clients; that they needed to inform their clients of the existence and receipt of the documents. That could have the effect of alerting possible suspects in NCA investigations to the fact of the investigation, allowing them to conceal or destroy evidence or go into hiding. The proposed amendment will help to prevent that happening again and will clarify the legal position of these financial institutions. They wanted to obey the law but were put in a difficult position vis-a-vis their clients. The amendment will help to clarify what Parliament intends in that regard.

I understand that the Opposition will move an amendment to certain provisions in this area. Whereas a member had a discretion to include a notation which could be exercised where he was satisfied that failure to include a notation might prejudice the safety, reputation or fair trial of a person or prejudice the effectiveness and the investigation which was otherwise in the public interest, the Opposition is proposing that where the member is reasonably satisfied that the above matters would be prejudiced he must include the notation. That seems to me to be a sensible amendment and the Government will accept it.

In this whole series of amendments, we are concerned with protecting the reputation of suspects at a time when allegations have not been properly investigated. I believe that the potential for damage to the reputation of people, through the disclosure of the existence of a summons or notice, is so significant that we have to make safeguards within the legislation. That is what we are going to do.

I believe—I know that I am increasingly in a minority in this respect—that the National Crime Authority should operate in secret. I am not a believer in the public parading of persons against whom allegations have been made, otherwise than in a court of law and according to the proper rules of evidence. I have always regarded the National Crime Authority as being a better model for the investigation of these sorts of allegations than, for example, the commission that operates in New South Wales. I believe that people can have their reputations irreparably damaged by allegations which are made without regard to the rules of evidence and on a standard of proof which in the end, even if findings are made, would not satisfy a jury or criminal court. In that respect, I believe that the National Crime Authority is a better model, more like the grand jury system in the United States, than the royal commission in open session in Australia. These are some of the matters which I believe are dealt with in this Bill.

Honourable senators from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have indicated their support for the Bill. Senator Crichton-Browne asked when the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Who is to Guard the Guards? will be responded to by the Government. It is intended that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) will respond to that report in the autumn session. Quite clearly, the Government has a report to which it needs to give very detailed and deliberate consideration, as does the Intergovernmental Committee of the NCA. One has to recall that the elected Ministers from all of the jurisdictions around Australia have a democratic role, a very necessary role, in our democracy in supervising the operations of the National Crime Authority. The Ministers would want to have the opportunity to consider the PJC report.

I believe that the Senate will have the benefit of that response in the autumn session next year, which will further strengthen the relationship which has to exist between the National Crime Authority, this Parliament and its committees. Only if we are confident that an authority vested with extraordinary powers, such as the National Crime Authority has, is under the proper supervision of the elected representatives of the people can we avoid sliding into the sometimes hysterical reaction to criminal activity which can vest enormous powers in law enforcement bodies but without sufficient democratic control of the exercise of those powers. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
