TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which relates to the second amendment with respect to the provision of information and general references going to the States. I refer to the point that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) made in the second reading debate about the role of the IGC. The IGC will be required to look at the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority with respect to section 51.

PARA.TAB: I think that the IGC's performance has been abysmal; it has failed in every single aspect of its obligations and responsibilities. It is a pompous committee which lectured and hectored the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority to the point where it had the audacity to suggest that that one proper effective watchdog should be abolished. To my knowledge, not one single reference which has been undertaken by the National Crime Authority since day one has come from the IGC. Between July 1984 and October 1991, the IGC has met on 16 occasions, and on each occasion for a matter of hours. That is the level of its monitoring.

During that period we had the imbroglio of Operation Ark, the controversy surrounding Justice Stewart and Mr Farris and the machinations that were going on in the Authority without any direction, guidance or supervision from the IGC. It seems to have done absolutely nothing to address the problems. From my inquiries, it seems that it has washed its hands—or not been capable—of making any suggestions.

As I recall, subsection 61(6) of the Act provides that the IGC may comment on the Authority's annual report and any comments made are required to be tabled in the Parliament with the report. The Government explained in 1984 that this provision was suggested by the State Ministers in discussion with the Commonwealth Ministers, and the Government saw no objection to it. It served to underline the cooperative scheme of the Bill. It might have done that, but it has done absolutely nothing else. The report says that the IGC made comments amounting to less than a page on each of the first three annual reports to the Authority. There have been no comments at all made by the IGC since the first three reports from 1984 onward. That lack of comment from the IGC strengthened the Committee's view and continues to strengthen its view that the IGC has not actively monitored the Authority. Many of the problems that the Authority has had over the years should have been dealt with directly by the IGC.

I find it not only audacious but also impertinent for the IGC to dare even to contemplate the abolition of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is the only body that sought or attempted to monitor the activities of the National Crime Authority. When we pursued the question of section 51, to give us a greater capacity to probe more effectively and more responsibly the activities of the National Crime Authority for the purpose of reporting to the Parliament and then to the wider community, we found that the IGC had frustrated our endeavours and ultimately suggested that the Committee be abolished.

When I challenged one of the police Ministers, Mr Edwards from Western Australia, as to the grounds, he said it was something he thought he read in the West Australian newspaper. It is hardly a responsible and proper way of making assessments about the competence and the practices of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority.

I do not mind supporting an amendment which provides that the activities of the National Crime Authority in respect of general references go directly to the State authorities, but I expect the State authorities to fulfil their obligations and their responsibilities, which thus far they have not done.

In conclusion, when we contemplate legislation of the nature that we presently have—which is capable of putting a prohibition on the disclosure by somebody served a summons of knowledge of that to somebody else—it is important to remember that we are very much tampering and interfering with the normal rights of individual citizens of Australia. We are now interfering with the normal practices and rights and, in many respects, obligations and responsibilities, for instance, of financial institutions in respect of their clients.

We are now putting ourselves in a situation, judged necessary in pursuit of criminality, of preventing a bank from disclosing to one of its depositors inquiries about the depositor, inquiries about information contained in the bank being disclosed to an individual, in the same way as we are interfering with the normal relationship between a lawyer and a client—a relationship held almost unique and special in the minds of most Australians, second only to the relationship between a doctor and his patient.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask whether the Acting Leader agrees with his Labor Party colleague Peter Duncan who, when it was put to him by an interviewer on Adelaide radio this morning that:

QUESTION.PARA: John Hewson sold himself as a man of vision and a man who could actually see a future for Australia, and so it's absolutely essential that the Labor Party come up with someone who can match that notion of leadership, isn't it?
Yes, I agree with you about that.
I ask whether he also agrees with Peter Duncan's statement later in the interview in relation to Labor's leadership woes that:

The quicker the matter is brought to a head, the better. Some people are suggesting nothing should be done till February because of the visit by George Bush. Well, frankly, I wouldn't think it would matter much if Bob Hawke welcomed him and somebody else farewelled him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never agreed with him in my life.
—I am not in quite the same position as Senator Collins, who just interjected; the last time I agreed with Peter Duncan was December 1978.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and it concerns East Timor. Does the Minister believe it is appropriate for him, or anyone else in his place, to sign an agreement this week with Indonesia which will allow oil and gas exploration in the Timor Sea, coming as it does only a month after the massacre in Dili and the subsequent efforts of the Indonesian military to cover up what happened there? Given the growing concern in the United States Congress and in Europe about Indonesia's appalling record in East Timor since 1975 and the plea by the East Timorese delegation which met with the Minister on 3 December for Australia to support East Timor's right to self-determination, does the Government now accept not only that it is inappropriate to pursue the division of spoils under the Timor Sea with Indonesia but also that Australia should now move to use the good offices of the United Nations in the future of East Timor as Australia has supported and promoted recent United Nations initiatives in Yugoslavia and Cambodia?

—The agreement being signed this week is very much pursuant to the treaty which already exists between Indonesia and Australia on the Timor Gap question. It would be a very serious matter indeed were Australia not to proceed with its obligations under that existing treaty arrangement, which was freely entered into between two sovereign countries and is pursuant to what was obviously a de jure recognition by us—announced as such in 1979 and repeated by this Government in 1985—so far as Indonesia's sovereignty over the border area in question is concerned.

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances of the present East Timor situation, it is the case—as I have made clear on numerous previous occasions—that the Government does not believe, on any evidence presently available to us, that what happened there, deplorable as it was, was something that could be construed as an act of state: a calculated or deliberate act of the Government as such. As such, it has to be regarded as quite distinct from the actions of government which were involved in the Tiananmen Square exercise in China or in the context of the administration of the apartheid regime in South Africa.

So long as we continue to make that judgment about the nature of the Dili massacre—that it was not an act of state but the product of aberrant behaviour by a subgroup within the country—it would be utterly inappropriate for us to take any steps which would bring the bilateral relationship into disrepair. It would certainly be quite inappropriate for us to even contemplate taking a step so grave as to, in effect, tear up a solemn international treaty entered into between two countries. That is not a step the Government is prepared to take.

We have said that in the event that the investigation presently under way should prove to be manifestly unsatisfactory—and, of course, we all hope very much that that will not be the case—then we will be prepared to review the whole nature of our relationship with Indonesia and the bilateral contacts that are associated with the East Timor question. I have said that before, the Prime Minister has said it, and that remains the case.

In the meantime, we are actively pursuing a number of issues with the Indonesians and I will, of course, be pursuing these very directly and in very great detail next week during my visit there. One of those issues is the role of the United Nations. We do believe it would be very appropriate indeed were the Secretary-General, in the exercise of his good offices, to send an envoy or a representative—perhaps one of the special rapporteurs on particular subject matters who do exist in the UN system—to enter into discussions with the Indonesian authorities on the conduct of the inquiry and perhaps participate in some supportive way in that inquiry to give added confidence in it to witnesses and, of course, to the international community, and to assist in the process of discussing means of effective reconciliation between the East Timor people and the Indonesian Government. There is genuinely, we believe, a role for the United Nations in that respect. We hope very much that the Indonesian Government will see it that way. That is one of the issues that I will be actively pursuing in Jakarta next week.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I put it to Senator Evans that the existing Timor Gap treaty should be put on hold pending the present inquiry and the hoped for United Nations inquiry. I further ask whether Senator Evans really expects ordinary citizens of East Timor to come before that Indonesian Government inquiry when they are threatened yet again by Sutrisno, the commander of the armed forces, who has said that after the inquiry is over they will, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . wipe out and uproot the disturbance movement which has tainted the government's dignity.

In Senator Evans's estimation, is this Indonesian Government inquiry worth anything at all? Is it not completely lacking in credibility when citizens of East Timor are scared for their lives if they dare to speak out to that inquiry?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of doing anything as simple as putting the treaty arrangements on ice. There is a plan of operational activity; there is a course of action that has been identified as appropriate and indeed required under that particular treaty. The time for taking that further step has arrived, and it would, as I say, be a very serious act indeed and in effect amount, as I understand it, to a breach possibly of our treaty obligations were we not to proceed with those arrangements this week.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular remarks attributed to General Sutrisno this week, they are obviously regrettable, if accurate. I certainly am seeking an opportunity, and I believe I will have the opportunity, to meet with General Sutrisno when I visit Indonesia next week. I will certainly be making very clear to him and to other members of the Government just how regrettable and how manifestly unacceptable we regard the sentiments attributed to him as being, and how unhappy those sentiments are from the point of view of Indonesia's national interests and international reputation.

I hope that, in an atmosphere of slightly more restrained discussion than it is possible to conduct at this distance in this currently rather troubled environment, it will be possible to make some of those points effectively in a way that will have some effect. I can only try.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of the Reserve Bank's intervention in the financial markets in the last 48 hours, will the Minister clarify the Government's immediate intention for monetary policy and state whether it intends to stabilise the currency or, as has been suggested by some dealers, it intends to see the Australian dollar plummet to $US0.75?

—Mr President, since our decision to float the Australian dollar in 1983, the level of the dollar has been determined by the market. I simply do not propose to comment on any question relating to fluctuations in the Australian dollar. Senator Bishop should be responsible enough to appreciate that that is the only possible reply.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In that case I wonder whether the Minister could explain to me how we have had two different statements, one from the Prime Minister and one from the Treasurer, where the Prime Minister said on radio yesterday that the Government would ease monetary policy `if there is room for it' and `if it is economically responsible' and, on the other hand, the previous day the Treasurer said—and this is Mr Willis, just in case the Minister has forgotten who it is—he would dismiss calls to pump prime the economy. Which of them is correct, or are they merely both incompetent?

—Mr President, it is manifestly the case that Senator Bishop's understanding of economic concepts and jargon is as limited as her understanding of the procedural requirements of this place. When one is talking about monetary policy in the particular context that was in issue there one is talking about interest rate policy. When one is talking about pump priming, one is talking about fiscal policy and the government expenditure that is necessarily involved in that. Exchange rate policy is a subset of monetary policy, if one likes, but is something different again. If Senator Bishop does not start beginning to understand the difference between those economic concepts, she will have even less credibility as a leadership contender on her side than she does at the moment, which is saying something.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to recent comments by Mrs Carolyn Hewson, who has called for tax deductibility for child-care expenses. As a working mother, I ask the Minister, on behalf of the millions of other working parents: does the Government agree that there should be some income tax concession available for child-care expenses? Does the Minister agree that rebates are a much fairer method of providing assistance to working parents than deductions because everybody obtains the same benefit? Finally, when is the Government going to acknowledge the greater costs which are borne by working parents and provide equitable tax relief for them?

—The Government's basic position is that it simply would not be equitable or efficient to provide assistance for child-care through the taxation system, given the need to target government assistance of this kind in a sensible way. Moreover, it is the case that the Government already provides generous assistance for child-care through the Budget. Let me justify those two statements.

PARA.TAB: As to our present assistance, we do provide income tested fee relief for child-care for eligible families using approved services including non-profit, commercial and employer sponsored services. The advantages of providing assistance in this way are that it is targeted according to need, it provides for monitoring and maintenance of standards of child-care facilities and it limits scope for abuse that could be associated with assistance provided through the tax system.

The trouble with providing tax deductibility for work related child-care, as attractive a concept as that often seems to people at first blush—it is certainly something that has been considered over the years by successive governments—is that in the first place it tends to assist those whose incomes are highest, the value of deductibility of course being determined by the taxpayer's marginal rate. This would not apply to a tax rebate, I acknowledge, which would be at a set rate per dollar of expense. Again, the value of tax deductibility or of an expense related rebate is determined by the level of relevant expenditure. That could be mitigated by capping the level of eligible expenditure, that is true; but there is a problem of that kind.

Secondly, it would add a complication to the taxation system. Employee pay-as-you-earn deduction arrangements would need to be varied for individual employees as their deduction rebate varied. An additional item would need to be included in the information provided to and considered by income tax payers when preparing their returns. These sorts of administrative complications are not insignificant as marginal—not central—considerations.

The third consideration is that it could open up avenues for abuse, especially excessive child-care payments for family members. This could be mitigated by narrowing eligibility, but at quite considerable cost in terms of complexity of legislation, compliance and administration. They are the reasons that traditionally have been articulated by the Government for going down the route of targeted child-care rather than tax deductibility. That is the basis on which we are presently administering policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer him to the costings of the coalition's Fightback plan by the Department of Finance, in which the Department said that the lowering of the qualifying age of the youngest dependent child from 16 years to 12 years for the sole parent pension `would address recognised work disincentives, particularly for part-time work, facing sole parent pensioners and would be consistent with the direction of policy in recent years towards lower dependence on income support'. Does the Minister therefore feel like an absolute goose—to borrow Senator Evans's latest term of endearment—now that his dishonest scare campaign of recent days regarding this aspect of the coalition's package has been refuted by another Minister? Was Senator Richardson consulted beforehand about this matter or about Finance's endorsement of the coalition's policy in relation to the pension paid to the wives of disability support pensioners? If not, does Senator Richardson accept that the new Treasurer, Mr Willis, released these comments from Finance to present yet another rebuff to Senator Richardson, who has been attempting to have his portfolio exempted from the economic review committee process?

—What a top question. As a matter of fact, I would have thought all honourable senators would recall that it is only a few days since Senator Crowley asked me a question to the effect that has the Government ever considered a reduction of the age from 16 years to 12 years. I said yes. There is no great secret about it. Of course, when the Department of Finance rolled it up, I rolled it over. I might say that I was able to do that without great effort. Anyone who is a Cabinet member will recall that the Government rolled this very easily.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston has to understand that this Department of Finance is an independent, fearless group of men and women who do not necessarily accept everything that the Government puts up because they have some of their own ideas. Ideas like this get rolled up from time to time and when they get rolled up they get rolled over. They get rolled over by Labor governments because we will not accept the extraordinary, cruel consequences of ever taking that kind of action.

We will never accept, not for a second, that parenting cannot remain an option for a quarter of a million Australian women who wish it to be so. We will not cop that. Yes, it has been suggested and, yes, it has been knocked back—and it will continue to be knocked back. It will not be knocked back because of any brilliance of my oratory; it gets knocked back because none of my Cabinet colleagues accept that it is a reasonable course of action. The easiest brief one will ever get in Cabinet is knocking that one over.

With regard to the wives of disability support pensioners, I think the same argument applies. From time to time one gets the hard-edged Finance option. But what one also gets from this Government is a willingness to examine beyond the need to crush people—to try to work out where one should target social security expenditure and where one should target one's efforts at fraud control. We will never—I repeat never—target the hundreds of thousands of people that the Opposition has managed to target in this package, under which life for them would become more miserable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the commercial support program, announced as part of the force structure review, is progressing? Has the Minister seen claims that further savings of up to $500m could be made to the Defence budget, redirecting $300m to enhance combat capability and returning $200m to Consolidated Revenue? Does the Minister intend to implement such proposals?

—The commercial support program that Defence is currently undertaking had its genesis in the Wrigley report on the force structure review. For instance, between 1993 and 1995 the program will bring about savings of around $510m. The reason it can bring about such substantial savings without other costs is that it was very much crafted to meet the attrition rate that occurs in the armed services. We have a situation where it basically motors along on the attrition rate and does not require redundancies.

PARA.TAB: I have seen some very confused proposals around which vary from day to day. I saw one suggestion today that a future government may in fact contemplate a $200m return to Consolidated Revenue over three years. It is a pity that the person who put that out had not read the source material because, when one reads the source material and the tables, they suggest that $450m over three years will be returned to Consolidated Revenue.

I am sorry that Senator Vallentine is not paying attention at the moment because here at last is Senator Vallentine's peace dividend: $450m over three years to be ripped out of the Defence budget. Senator Vallentine should smile because she has finally made it. She has finally got a major influence group in Australia wanting the payment of a peace dividend—to just rip it straight out of the Defence budget and plonk it back into Consolidated Revenue.

The real problem with this is that we are not given any real detail of how this is going to occur. Inferences are drawn that there will be large staff cuts. If, for instance, one wanted to save $500m over two years, it would be necessary to get rid of about 15,000 employees—say 10,000 civilians and 5,000 in the armed services. Of course, that overlooks a few matters. This proposal would involve redundancies. So what would happen in those first two years is that one would not get $300m redirected to the combat area and one would not get $200m in peace dividends plonked into Consolidated Revenue; one would have to pay back into Defence somewhere between $193m and $332m, according to the degree of contracting out of civilians.

These sorts of proposals floating around mean that, instead of saving money, in the initial years they will cost an enormous amount of money to fund from some section of government. That is the great difficulty and that is the great failure. Of course, eventually, in the fourth, fifth or sixth years, one starts to get savings, after having completely vandalised the Australian Defence Force.

I read today that there are other proposals around to make these savings. A very interesting suggestion from Senator Durack was to cut 10 per cent off every corporate service. It would involve reducing Comcare payments by 10 per cent, when there are statutory requirements. It would involve a 10 per cent cut in fringe benefit, yet that is fully supplemented to Defence and would bring about absolutely no savings.

The figure of 10 per cent is terribly interesting. I thought, `If an alternative government recommends all this, why don't we check its track record?', and I did. There is only one person sitting on the other side of the chamber who has ever been a Minister. I thought I would see how ruthless this person was when he was Attorney-General. Unfortunately, I found that under the stewardship of my colleague Senator Durack over there, the number of employees in the Attorney-General's Department went up 10 per cent. I found that the real growth in the expenditure of the Attorney-General's Department went up by 10 per cent over that time, well in advance of inflation. It is the old case of those who cannot do, teach.

What is particularly annoying to me—and this is why I will not implement these proposals—is that as Minister for Defence I have had to put up with a number of people opposite wandering around defence facilities saying, `Senator Ray is a mean Minister for Defence; we will pour more money in'. Yet in the first three years in government those opposite would effectively rip $450m out of Defence. They cannot do it by savings on personnel costs. In the end, if they insist on it, and I hope they do not, they will have to rip it out of capital equipment acquisitions—smile again, Senator Vallentine, this is right up your street—or operating costs. Smile again Senator Vallentine. Your speeches during the adjournment debate have obviously affected the Opposition.

The real tragedy is that the Government has been lectured to time and time again by the Opposition that we cannot be trusted on defence policy. For one reason or another, we are not to be entrusted with the guidance of defence. When it came to the crunch, Dr Hewson and others came up with these proposals—there was no consultation with any of their defence spokesmen. The people opposite who take an interest were not consulted at all. You might stare at me, Senator MacGibbon; you want 3 per cent of GDP for defence—an extra $2.5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has been debating this for a very long time. I ask you to ask him to direct his comments through the chair, which he is not doing.
—Order!

—Basically I agree with the point of order, so I will conclude on this note: the Government will not invoke these things. I put out the challenge directly to the shadow Ministers sitting opposite that if they are going to redirect $300m a year to enhance combat capability, if they are to rip off $200m a year and put it back into Consolidated Revenue, they should come out and say how they are going to do it. It should not be done through cheap press releases which say that they can take 10 per cent off everything when their record belies that.
—What are you doing about fraud control? You were going to do something about it. You haven't even started.

—The cargo cultism of Senator Newman and others is, `If only you do this, if only you do that'. The bottom line is that what the Opposition is planning to do to the Defence Force is pure vandalism. It goes against the traditions of its policies over the last 20 or 30 years, when it has tried to espouse that it is the proud upholders of the defence tradition. The Opposition is betraying the defence forces of Australia.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of comments made by the former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, at last Thursday's press conference on the national accounts that he knew that the farm result would be bad but, when framing the Budget in August, policy-makers had been unaware of just how long the drought plaguing south-eastern Queensland would last? I also point out to the Minister that these national accounts figures, which include drops in sugar and wool production, do not reflect the extent of the failure of winter cereal crops, which will not show up until the December quarter national accounts. In view of the fact that, prior to becoming Treasurer early this year, Mr Kerin had been the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy since 1983, does this admission mean that he had no knowledge or awareness of the extent of Australia's rural downturn, which has been steadily growing in the past few years, or did the Minister just fail to draw this growing problem to the attention of the policy-makers when framing his Budget?
—I answered a similar question from Senator Boswell earlier in the week. Some of us are just not quite as close to the right hand of the almighty as others in terms of getting—
—That is true.

—I am cheerfully prepared to concede that. There is some shortfall in Western Australia too in that respect. We cannot make completely confident judgments about how long adverse weather and drought conditions will prevail. I am totally confident—nothing that Mr Kerin said in his press conference in any way differs from this—that the best possible estimates of those physical conditions were fed into the national accounts assessments that were made and played in the Budget context.
—When the National Party was in office in Queensland, it had droughts most of the time.

—I readily endorse what Senator Walsh said. What the Government has simply been able to do in this situation is not change the weather patterns, change the reality of production or change the shortfalls which exist—obviously, in the short term we are not able to change the world market prices—but do the best we can to help those farmers who are adversely affected. We are acutely aware of how many in the rural community are experiencing great hardships, not only from the current dry conditions but also from the downturn in commodity prices.

PARA.TAB: The rural adjustment scheme is the Commonwealth's main avenue for providing support in those circumstances. Senator Bjelke-Petersen will remember that on 29 October we announced a $30m increase in Commonwealth funding for the RAS. In total, funding this year for that scheme has been increased by over $100m. We have also announced a new arrangement linking RAS assessments to social security benefits, which will inject another $10m into rural assistance this financial year. Those provisions will apply from 1 December and they will meet essential living expenses for those farmers who have prospects of longer term profitability but who are unable in the present conditions to obtain or service extra debt.

Moreover, the Commonwealth will be working with the States to develop a still more comprehensive Commonwealth drought policy, which includes the non-RAS recommendations of the drought policy review task force. Within the constraints imposed by the real world, we are doing the best we possibly can for that rural community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his very comprehensive answer to that matter. However, one thing I would like to know, in view of the problems that many rural people are having—the Minister assures us that the Government is trying to help them—is whether the Minister is aware that farmers aged 65 and over are ineligible for the Government's amended Jobsearch allowance.
—I will ask Senator Richardson to respond to that particular matter on my behalf.
—It was hardly a supplementary question, but I will allow the Minister to answer.

—All honourable senators would be aware that the Jobsearch allowance is not available to people aged over 65, and never has been. That is not a new development. When the Parliament debated only a week or so ago new arrangements to enable about 2,000 farmers to receive Jobsearch allowance, no-one in the chamber raised the question of whether it will be available to persons over 65. It is a payment that never has been made, either in its current form or in its previous form.

PARA.TAB: If there were a further attempt to allow persons over 65 to receive this allowance, we have to realise that very different tests would be put upon people. If we look at what happens to income earned under the JSA or income earned under the age pension, we see either a dollar for dollar withdrawal rate or a 50c in the dollar withdrawal rate. There are very different conditions.

I do not think that we as a government, or even the Opposition, can seriously contemplate—it has not been suggested before—opening up Jobsearch allowance to people over 65. If that is to place some farmers in extra difficulty, it is certainly a problem that I am happy to look at. It has been raised with me by Senator Boswell. I will certainly have a go. I do not think the solution will be found in making the Jobsearch allowance available to people over 65.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) to a question without notice asked by Senator Beahan this day relating to defence expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you be reasonably short?

—Yes, I will be short; it will not take long to refute the nonsense answer that was given. In answer to a question just a few minutes ago, the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, who has now left the chamber, made a number of comments. It seemed that the purpose of the question was to give him an opportunity to comment on the Fightback proposal in relation to the Defence portfolio. Senator Robert Ray entirely misrepresented the proposals of the Opposition in relation to Defence. Indeed, his whole contribution was so confused and so totally wrong that I can only assume that Senator Ray has many things of much greater priority on his mind today, and has had for some time. That is the most generous explanation I can find of why he should have made the claims that he has.

PARA.TAB: From page 230 of the Opposition's portfolio savings and expenditure proposals, table 16.1, which is headed `Summary of three year expenditure program', under the heading of `Defence', it is perfectly clear that over three years there is provision for a total decrease in outlays of $500m, for increases in outlays of $300m—that is, redirection of Defence spending out of that $500m—with a net saving of $200m. That is a net saving over three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1991-92 or 1990-91 dollars?

—These are in 1991-92 figures. It is quite clear; it always has been quite clear, though it is something Senator Evans did not seem to understand yesterday. We have not been in any confusion about this matter.

PARA.TAB: To make it perfectly clear, I issued a statement on the day that the Fightback package was launched by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). The expenditure proposals in relation to Defence were over three years, not over any one year. Senator Robert Ray came in here and claimed that the Opposition has suggested savings of $450m. He has taken that wrong assumption from the Department of Finance information given by the current Treasurer (Mr Willis) the other day. Finance itself seems to have become confused about what is perfectly clear—namely, that the savings proposed by the Opposition will be over a three-year period and the net savings will be only $200m, not $450m as Senator Robert Ray claims. Whether Finance has that misunderstanding or not is perhaps not clear from its own statements, but Senator Ray certainly made that claim in his answer to a question today and he is quite wrong. I totally refute that claim.

There was a quite remarkable criticism by Senator Ray about the number of Defence positions which would go if in fact what he seemed to think was a shock-horror proposal of the Opposition was put into effect. He claimed that over the three-year period 15,000 Defence jobs would go. I would like to draw attention to Senator Ray's much vaunted force structure review which he brought down in this place on 30 May this year. He was very fortunate that little attention was paid to the force structure review by the media or anybody else, because that was the day before the last challenge to Mr Hawke by Mr Keating. Senator Ray had further diversions.

The force structure review proposes that over this decade 10,450 jobs will be taken from Service personnel and 3,840 from civilian employees. On my arithmetic, over 14,000 jobs will be lost from Defence through the Government's own force structure review. I remind Senator Ray that, of the jobs that have been taken from Defence, over 5,000 will come from the regular combat forces—the Army and the Air Force. It is the Opposition's policy to ensure that the burden of savings in the Defence portfolio will come from the base support end, not from combat related areas. That is a firm commitment that we have made all along.

The major attack which Senator Ray has launched on the Opposition's defence proposals this afternoon are completely misdirected. He completely misunderstands the document. Senator Ray has just come back into the chamber. I draw his attention to page 230 of the Fightback! document, which is headed `Table 16.1: Summary of Three Year Expenditure Program'. It makes it perfectly clear that the savings from Defence will be only $200m. The honourable senator can shake his head, but he should look at that document and he will see that he is completely wrong.

Senator Ray talked about a number of other matters. I think he was referring to a release that I issued today showing that savings of over $300m can be made over a three-year period in administrative areas without the loss of any positions at all. Those savings were based on the Government's recently released defence commercial support manual, which has provided for the first time real details of administrative costs—not salaries and wages —such as travel and subsistence and office requisites, totalling over $1 billion a year. The one and only quote that Senator Ray made from this release was in relation to fringe benefits, which represented a small saving of $500,000. There will be savings in computer services and advertising of $20m a year. So there is a huge area of fat in the Department of Defence in administration costs—not salaries and wages. Out of that alone, we can save over $300m out of the $500m, as stated in the Fightback proposal.
I have risen this afternoon simply to refute the totally inaccurate, misleading and completely wrong statements made by Senator Ray in his answer to a question today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —If anyone is forced to make a comment on what the Fightback package means in defence, one is first of all limited by the fact that a mere 1 1/2 pages, 9 paragraphs in all, are devoted to what is 10 per cent of government expenditure, one of the most critical areas of government policy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Durack has again indicated just how totally confused he is. He should read his own document. His own document factors in a $50m saving in the first year, $200m in the second year and $200m in the third year, which will go back to Consolidated Revenue. It is quite clearly there in the Opposition's document.

In addition to that, having saved that money and sent it back to Consolidated Revenue, the Opposition believes it can generate $300m to put back into the combat end. What is the Opposition saying? Today, Senator Durack appears to be saying, `Well, that will be over three years. That is only $100m a year over three years'. That is not spelt out at all in the document.

I said earlier that during my tenure as Defence Minister I have heard many Opposition members make pleas for larger defence expenditure. Senator MacGibbon, both in the Hansard and I think by way of press release today, argues that in a good and perfect world we would be spending 3 per cent of GDP on defence. I do not quarrel with the figure in terms of what should be done in an ideal world. I do not even say that Senator MacGibbon argues that it would go up by that much in one hit, that is, $2.5 billion. However, I find the dichotomy of that argument running quite contrary to what is in the Fightback package.

I have already been through the essence of the Opposition's proposal. Where does it get the savings? Senator Durack argues that his 10 per cent off everything saves $100m and the rest of the savings will be made through commercial support. As I went through it fairly carefully, I found the current commercial support program runs along the line of the attrition rate in defence. So when we want to do more, we can do more, but that immediately starts reducing personnel numbers even more. Senator Durack says that the Government will reduce them by 14,000. It is all factored in. Senator Short says that the Opposition is not going to do anything additional to that; it will just take our savings. Senator Durack is not arguing that. He is saying that the Opposition is going to do something additional.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your savings are so slow.

—Oh, $510m in that period is really slow! How much did Senator Durack save when he was in charge of the Attorney-General's Department? Expenditure went through the roof. The number of his employees went through the roof. Senator Durack is no ruthless cutter; he is just an old-fashioned mercantilist, pretending to be dry, but we will let that go by. To achieve the Opposition's commercial support program what is involved is making redundant, eliminating, sacking—whatever term you like to use—existing personnel and having outsiders do the job. On average, that is 20 per cent cheaper than having uniformed people, and in the far out years a higher percentage than 20 per cent could be achieved. To do that, the Opposition goes below the attrition rate and it has to go straight into redundancies.
—We allow for redundancies in this package.
—No, the Opposition does not.
—Yes, we do.
—Well, Senator, that is interesting.
—You read the table.

—I will come right back and point this out to Senator Durack: read the whole 700 pages because the Opposition allows $200m in the overall package for redundancies, and then on another page the Opposition specifically exempts industrial relations and defence from the package. It specifically exempts those areas and says that they are not part of the $200m. The only inference any sensible person can draw is that the redundancies will have to be absorbed in the defence area, because there is no allocation in the rest of the program for those redundancies.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is talking about getting $500m in savings from redundancies. I have used just one example today. If 15,000 people go, we still do not make $500m over two years. The Opposition would have to pay these people redundancies at a reasonable rate, plus bring forward and pay off their long service leave, pay off their accrued holiday leave and other entitlements, and bring forward the cost of their pensions. The Opposition will have to bring forward the pensions for each person it lets go—either civil or military. In a lot of cases, we are talking about lump sums. The cost to the overall totality of government policy means that in the end, to make those savings, which are achievable in the far out years—I totally acknowledged that in my answer today—the Opposition will have to put the money in first.

There is no use saying that we have allowed for 14,000 to go. That is on the attrition rate. Every cut the Opposition makes will have to be paid for in terms of redundancy and brought forward pensions. The massive costing comes in, if that happens to be the alternative way, through commercial support. I suppose I could ask: is the Opposition going to get rid of civilians? If it is, will it contract out any of their services? There is dead silence again, because this has been discussed in only nine paragraphs. There is a fair bit of detail in this. We want to know at what rate the Opposition is going to contract out. The Opposition does not say so, or is it just saying that it can move in and sack 5,000 or 10,000 civilians out of a total of 24,000, get exactly the same product and have no problems?
I have been through the Liberal proposals in some detail but they are very hard to cost and one has to use a variety of assumptions as examples simply because of the paucity of detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean you haven't been able to tear it down. There are no black holes.

—The Opposition spends nine paragraphs saying virtually nothing. It says it will send $200m back to Consolidated Revenue and have another $300m worth of savings. There is absolutely nothing. The Opposition, and Senator Crichton-Browne would know this because he is pretty experienced, says when there is a party room revolt over this, `Hey fellas, we did not really mean this and we will have an inquiry afterwards and we will try to fob you off'.

PARA.TAB: What happened, for the information of Senator Crichton-Browne, is that the shadow Minister for defence was not consulted on these cuts before the shadow Cabinet meeting. The figures did not add up and the shadow Cabinet got a bit desperate so it thought, `We have to pay a couple of hundred million dollars out of there and a few hundred million out of there and a few hundred million out of there'. Then when the shadow Cabinet put it to the shadow Minister, what could he say? `Yes, I can deliver'.

Of course anyone would say that. I would have said it, too. The shadow Cabinet has spent the last few weeks trying to work out how it can deliver. It has not worked it out at all. Senator Alston, Senator Short and Senator Durack may want to get up and say, `There will be no staff cuts in defence. We will not have any savings that particular way', which means the Opposition cannot then contract out through the commercial support program; it will have to find the money somewhere else. It can go the cargo cult route of Senator Newman: `Yes, we can find it here with fraud. We will find it here and we will find it there'—and all the rest of the rubbish she goes on with as the shop steward for the colonels. She does that all the time without being able to prove one thing.

Some of these proposals remind me of the difference between possibility and probability. It is possible to birdie every hole of 18 holes of golf. It is not very probable. It is possible to make some savings in the third, fourth, fifth and sixth out-year. But if in the meantime the Opposition rips the money out of defence and it cannot make the savings through staff cuts or in other areas, it has to take it off the more vital areas—or it has to renege on the promise.

That raises another question not central to defence. If the Opposition cannot deliver that money back to Consolidated Revenue, how do we bring about a proper compensation package or tax cuts? If the Opposition does not have the money, it cannot do it, and this is just one example of several departments where the Opposition will not be able to do it.

I draw this point to the Senate's attention: the Opposition wants to save $500m. The most extreme advocate of that, I think one could fairly say, and not in a critical way, is Mr Alan Wrigley, who said that we might be able to get savings of $350m a year, not calculating in redundancies, in the sixth out-year. That was with massive cuts, much more than under the force structure review—much more even than the Opposition had ever contemplated in its wildest fantasy. It would have rejected such cuts.

That is the most optimistic scenario Mr Wrigley, with a degree of double counting, could ever put on the public record. So there is a serious credibility problem with these proposals. We do look for more substance than we have heard today. We do look for a proper proposal that can be quite fairly costed. With a ready reckoner and fair officials, rather than just looking through the political bias which may be on my side, we might be able to put these figures through the wringer to see whether they are feasible.

We on this side have to fight a phantom. There are no detailed proposals. Why do we have no detailed proposals? Because those opposite do not have the intellectual calibre and stature to run them through at the moment. The Opposition has used the typical political ploy, which all of us in our careers at some stage have used, of saying, `We will have an inquiry'.

There are one or two other points that this nine paragraphs is silent on and on which the rest of the document is not clear. We have calculated that the cost of GST to Defence is $744m in purchases. No-one is going to come in here and run a scare campaign to suggest—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't know a thing about the package.
—Hold on. No-one is going to come in here and run a scare campaign that suggests that somehow Defence will get stuck with a bill for $744m.
—Do you think Defence is subject to GST?
—Senator Durack should wait. I said if GST were applied to Defence—
—But it is not.

—I am coming to that. Senator Short just wants to interrupt. It would cost $744m. But I ask the Opposition: will it exempt or supplement Defence? Silence. Will the Opposition exempt or supplement? Will the Opposition exempt Defence from GST at the source?
—Defence purchases are exempt from GST.
—I see. The Opposition is going to exempt them. It is not going to supplement the Budget, as it does with customs duties?
—It is in the document.
—I see. Where in the document?
—In the technical paper on GST.

—What page? The honourable senator does not know. We have been through those documents and the position is totally unclear. There is a difficulty when things are exempted. The great difficulty in exempting things is that someone is needed to police the system; some extra bureaucracy is needed to go through it. It is much quicker and much cheaper of course, in one sense, to do as we do with customs duties and supplement those payments to Defence. But of course we would have to find the $744m somewhere else in the document—and it does not appear. That is why I ask those opposite the question—
—It does appear. You haven't read the document.
—The honourable senator has just answered that $744m supplementation appears.
—You don't need supplementation because GST doesn't apply to defence purchases.

—Poor old Senator Short has just interjected that it is in the document but we do not need it because it is not there. It is like the invisible man. What the honourable senator is essentially saying to us is that there will be exemptions. Who determines the exempt nature of what and what bureaucracy is required are not factored into these proposals.

PARA.TAB: Let us move on to two or three other points to show how shabby, shallow and poorly thought-through this document is. It says this: `We are going to save money in Defence by halving the use of the VIP fleet, 34 Squadron'. Anyone knows that the cost of that is attributable to Administrative Services and not Defence. That is where the charge is made. Honourable senators opposite probably know —maybe even Senator MacGibbon would have a clear idea—that halving usage does not halve the cost. That is for a variety of reasons. VIP aircraft fly around empty while people get their flying hours up, for a start; and of course there is no clawback for commercial tickets forgone. The comments on the VIP fleet are hairshirt statements such as, `Let's knock the pollie mentality. Let's ride the wave. Let's abuse ourselves'. This is so popular in oppositions. It is reflected through a lot of areas. I will live with that. I do not mind that type of cheap shot being taken but it does not deliver the savings, and it certainly does not deliver the savings to Defence. The idea of having five leased Falcons flying around empty while people get up their hours, with no recouping of tickets, is absolutely ridiculous.

The second area I think I should address is the effect of some other proposals on superannuation. It really takes a bit of reading of the document to try to establish what effects it would have on superannuation. In the Opposition's policy, retirees have to wait and retire at age 60 or an early specified retiring age. That is fine. We have a lot of early specified retiring ages in Defence. Our real problem, of course, is that 99 per cent leave before they get to the specified point. So this particular provision, unless those opposite today or in the next couple of days say that they will exempt Defence, will have a devastating effect. I ask Senator Newman to think that through because it is not part of defence policy; it is another part of the package. I ask her to think through the effect that a flat 20 per cent tax on lump sums will have on people in the Services compared with people in other occupations, given the traditions of people moving out of the Services.

There is, of course, a third claim in this substantive factual material. The claim is made that ADI head office has gone from 1,300 to 42 staff. The fact is that most reductions occurred when Williamstown dockyard was sold and the Government Aircraft Factories went off to ASTA. So it is not a question of ADI coming down by that much. When ADI was set up, the number went from 1,300 to 300. So the reduction—we should correct this in the Opposition's document—is from 300 to 90. That is a good figure, by the way; it is a very impressive figure. But the figure of 42 is rubbish because those people are in one head office and other head office officials are distributed around a variety of factories. So this great claim that we can just cut the fat off the top and knock the figure down from 1,300 to 42 becomes a still reasonable claim that we can knock it down from 300 to 90. But, by gee, there was not much homework put into that, was there?

What we have here is a shambles of a policy. Back in January these people opposite, with a great fanfare and a great deal of opportunism, trying to differentiate themselves from the Government on the Gulf war, set up a defence review. This was to report, according to the press release, within three or four months.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was never—
—That is what was stated at the time. How many times has it met? Dead silence. I will tell the Senate: it has met four times.
—It has not.
—How many times?
—Six or seven.

—Six or seven meetings. How many position papers has it produced? Absolutely none. Those opposite have done nothing. They have sat there and slept through 11 months of their shadow Ministry. They have had 11 months of doing nothing but bludging off us in an opportunistic way, saying we were all wrong in our strategic assumptions with regard to the Gulf war. With great fanfare from Dr Hewson the Opposition set up an inquiry. We are told it has met six or seven times—I believe it is four, but I will not challenge that—and it has not produced one position paper.

PARA.TAB: In the Fightback package there are nine paragraphs—1 1/2 pages in 700—on cuts to defence spending. There is no relationship between that and what the tables show, which the Opposition has tried to obfuscate today. We have a shadow Minister sitting here telling us we can cut everything by 10 per cent, yet when he was Attorney-General the number of staff in that Department went up by 10 per cent and the real growth of expenditure went beyond 10 per cent. That is what we are facing at the moment. Also in the Fightback package there are sections on superannuation that will decimate the Defence Force.

I have two agendas in front of me and I will be blunt. There is always a political agenda to raise these things. As a loyal member of the Government, I have a political agenda to blow holes where there are obvious holes, and also to enter into dialogue to make sure that I am not involved in a sham or something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Loyal to whom? You have switched to Keating, haven't you?

—I can tell Senator Macdonald that I have a second obligation which not all Ministers have. All Ministers who become Minister for Defence have an obligation to the future of the defence forces—if not the day they sign up, certainly within two or three weeks. It leaves a mark on one's life for ever. I want to see a secure and proper future for the defence forces and not some cheap opportunist political trick to rip money off defence to no effect. Too much of that seems to be coming through in the Opposition's defence policy.

PARA.TAB: I will give some examples. Reference is made in the nine paragraphs to the Minehunter program. Several governments have been involved with that. Opposition senators obviously forget that they were in control of the Minehunter program for 7 1/2 years too, and did nothing. In opposition they say, `As part of our wonderful defence policy we will acquire Minehunters'. That is exactly what we are currently doing within the tightest possible timetable.

The Opposition says it will pick up early warning aircraft. We are also committed to that, but at least our commitment runs parallel with technological development. If the Opposition, possibly having been elected in 1993, rushed into an immediate purchase, it would find that within two to three years technology would have advanced so much as to reduce the cost by 75 per cent.

These are the sorts of infantile views that we hear too often. I do not want to delay the chamber—no doubt, other senators want to make their views known on this subject. In summary, there are great problems with what the Opposition proposes in its nine paragraphs—1 1/2 pages.

I will divert for a moment to something I have overlooked. This morning a press release was put out under Senator Durack's name. It says, `One of the ways we will save $108m in the first year and maybe the second year is to cut 10 per cent off absolutely everything'. How do we take 10 per cent off the Comcare premium when it is a statutory requirement? How do we take 10 per cent off the fringe benefit tax bill, when Defence does not pay it and is fully supplemented for it? That was part of the agreement at the time.

How do we take 10 per cent off defence removal costs? Do we just pull it off the budget? Do we drive to Alice Springs and say, `Look, walk the rest of the way to Darwin'. This is infantile. I concede, though—and I will be fair—that there are three or four things on this list which could have 10 per cent taken off without it being the end of the world. Let me go to some of them. In advertising, 10 per cent of $19.94m is $1.994m. I hate to tell honourable senators opposite, but we are looking to try to take $4m off that figure at the moment. But I totally agree that that is achievable.

What about medical and dental services. Do we fill up 90 per cent of a cavity and leave 10 per cent unfilled? Where do we go with that? Postage and telephone costs have been screwed down enormously already. I doubt that a 10 per cent saving can be made in these areas. This proposal is glib, it is cheap and it is political. I just repeat that this is not real defence analysis; this is not real financial analysis.

I challenge honourable senators opposite to bring forward their detailed defence plans. If they are good, I will acknowledge that. But I ask honourable senators opposite to cost them properly. We will put them through the wringer as well. We will cost them and see how they come out—but only on the figures which the Opposition produced in 1977, 1980 and 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get the public servants to do it again.
—I do not ask them and I never would ask them to do political work, and the honourable senator knows that. I would never do that.
—What have they been doing for the last three weeks?
—For the last three weeks, the Department of Defence has been working as normal.
—The Finance Department.
—I see. The honourable senator is off on a frolic of his own. I will just leave him up in fairyland.

PARA.TAB: It is up to the Opposition to prove that this is not a stunt, to prove to me why we need to take $200m out and put it into Consolidated Revenue. Why is the Opposition's statement on the table different? Who is right and who is going to prevail? If the Opposition cannot deliver those cuts—and this is replicated over other departments—how is it going to afford its compensation package; how is it going to afford its tax cuts, et cetera? Or is the bottom line what I suspect? What the Opposition is really going to do is get into privatisation and asset sales, not retire debt, and fund the three years, because that is all it is going to be left with under these proposals.

I believe that we are at our absolute minimum in respect of defence expenditure. I have achieved the objective described by the rather grotesque term `nought per cent real growth'. That term describes what has happened in the last two years. Nought per cent real growth means that there has been no real cut in defence expenditure in the last two years. We are pretty confident we will get that result next year. We have also achieved a 100 per cent return on property sales and up to one per cent real growth. That leaves the defence forces with a good future, room for expansion, the majority of the pink book—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the new Prime Minister approve of this?
—The honourable senator is just bleating away and playing petty politics. He will never understand that maybe the defence of the nation is a bit more important than his dull and boring ego.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, there have not been cuts in defence. There has not been the growth in the Forward Estimates, either, which maybe a lot of people in this chamber would like to see. We are told that $200m will be ripped off. Senator Durack says that this will happen over three years. If he reads his document he will see that the amounts are $50m, $150m and $200m. That is what the document says; that is what the tables say.

Honourable senators opposite say that provision will be made for redundancies, when their own document specifically excludes Defence and Industrial Relations from those redundancy payments. They say that they can double the commercial support program of 14,000. But once they start to increase it, they would go below the attrition rate line and have to pay redundancies and bring forward pensions. Those are all costs to government. Some will be shown above the line, some below the line and some not at all because they will come out of another section of government.

But these matters throw serious doubt on the credibility of the Opposition's defence policy. If the Opposition gets its Dads' Army defence review to come up with a comprehensive policy in the next few weeks, we will have a good debate about it. But to meet four, five, six or seven times, to produce no position paper, to be barely consulted on this Fightback project and then to have to try to come up with some analyses afterwards to prove how it is going to make the savings is simply not good enough. It is not good enough from a party—and I do not acknowledge this—that would claim to be the great defenders of the defence tradition in this country. It is not an appropriate policy to betray the defence forces of Australia for cheap political reasons. They are far too important for that and the Opposition should rethink its policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has heard 26 minutes of an open, naked and unadorned political speech. That is perfectly reasonable in a political chamber. I just wish we had got to a little more fact.
—I do have an appointment; I am not being rude.

—I know. The Minister has just rehearsed his speech here. I hope he goes a little better at his press interview than he went in that speech. The Minister must have extraordinarily shallow political experience if he expects an Opposition to come out with a precisely detailed package of what they will do.

PARA.TAB: The issues are very clear for this country. We have had eight years of bungling incompetence, in which we have gone from a debt position of $30-odd billion to a debt of $135 billion or more. Somewhere between one-half and one-third of our export earnings are going just to pay the interest on that debt and the economy is in a really critical state. Everything else this Government has touched is in the same condition: the same cowboy approach has been brought to the affairs of state as a result of 8 1/2 years of this Government.
We in the Opposition are saying that we will do better. We will fix the mess—we will fix the mess economically and we will fix the Government's mess in all other departments of state.

It is quite unreal for Senator Ray to attack the members of the Opposition for not putting forward a detailed plan. Anyone who has been in politics for any length of time knows that that is not the role of the Opposition. The role of the Opposition, in presenting policies before an election, is to provide guideposts, to say, `This is where we're going to go and where we're going to take the country in these various areas'.

It is not for the Opposition to dot the last `i' or cross the last `t'. We simply cannot do that. In the first place, we do not have the information and, secondly, we do not have the resources. The Government has spent probably tens of millions of dollars in overtime, computer time and consultants' time looking at the GST package in the last three or four weeks. It has not been able to find a crack in it—not a fault.

But that is irrelevant. The important thing is that the Government has all of these resources to call on; we do not have those. We literally have to put our own money into writing policies. That really does not matter; it is the way it has always happened with oppositions. At least we have the ideas. Quite clearly, this Government has no ideas. It has lost all of its creative thought, if indeed it ever possessed much.

I turn to the reason why I am on my feet. I apologise if I misrepresent what Senator Ray said, but Senator Macdonald and Senator Olsen were talking to me at the time. I understood Senator Ray to say that I had put out a press release today saying that we needed 3 per cent of gross domestic product attributed to defence. I did put out an excellent press release this morning, but I certainly did not mention GDP in any part of it. The burden of my press release was that the Government operates its Department of Defence in accordance with two publications: the Defence of Australia 1987, the White Paper which was presented in 1987; and Australian Strategic Plans 1990. Those two publications, by the Government's own admission, define the priorities, duties and responsibilities of the Australian Defence Force.

My press release pointed out that, by the standards set by the Government in 1987, which were reconfirmed and modified slightly in 1990, the Government had failed to meet its own objectives. One of the essential points contained in DOA 1987 was that the defence vote had to grow by between 2.7 per cent and 3 per cent in real terms in order to achieve the objectives. I pointed out that the Government had never maintained adequate funding. In fact, since DOA 1987 was brought down, we have never had any growth in the defence budget. The defence vote actually declined in real terms in a couple of years. The best it has done in the other years is break even.

My press release pointed out that the Government ought to meet its own objectives and that that required, by its definition, between 2.7 per cent and 3 per cent real growth on the budget of the year before. I went on in my press release to talk about the fact that the Government had not met the capability and readiness requirements that were defined in its publications. So the Government fell down both in terms of funding and in the preparedness that was implicit in the documents.

Senator Ray had a great time, both part way through and at the end of his speech, attacking the Opposition about its review committee. I am totally at a loss to understand what he is on about there. We are not accountable to the Government of the day for the private committees we set up, the number of meetings we have or whom we talk with, and we do not have to seek his permission to bring a report down or anything like that. I know there is a totalitarian streak in the Labor Party as evidenced by the way it brought in the ban on advertising Bill last week and rammed it through with a jackbooted guillotine with the support of the Far Left branch of the Labor Party and the Democrats, but we are entitled to run our own review committees to develop our policies. We do not have to answer to the Government in any way at all.

I would have thought it very dangerous for the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to talk about the integrity and the probity of committees. Only this year we had a big committee set up in Defence—the Force Structure Review Committee. That Committee produced a report in March which the Government implemented and which led, amongst other things, to the setting up of the Ready Reserve. In the process it got rid of two of only six regular infantry battalions in the country, which is a huge loss. One-third of our capacity, of our combat regular forces, disappeared at the stroke of a pen. That Committee also made other recommendations.

The Force Structure Review Committee presented an extraordinarily shallow, superficial and intellectually indefensible report. No argument was advanced as to how it came to its conclusions, and one is left, without being too unkind about it, with the view that it was simply a political document created by the Government to initiate cost cutting measures. I do not wish to debate the findings of the Force Structure Review Committee here, but the very last person to be talking about committees and what they do should be the present Minister.

Of course, the position was exacerbated because, whilst the Minister has considerable ability, he has been totally preoccupied for the whole year with trying to keep his great mentor, Mr Hawke, in office. A consequence of that is that he has handed over not only the matters that should be transferred under the administrative arrangements to his junior Minister, Mr Bilney, but also a considerable number of policy decisions which are demonstrably way beyond Mr Bilney's intellectual or professional abilities to cope with. That has exacerbated the position within the Department of Defence because the Minister has not been putting the whole of his effort into running his Department.

The Minister tried to muddy the waters a bit by talking about some of the proposals we have made with respect to equipment. We do not want to go too far into the subject of equipment because we are certainly not in the business of presenting a shopping list to the people of Australia when we go to an election with our defence policy.

But it is quite wrong to attribute the losses of the minehunter inshore program to the previous Fraser Government. Goodness me, the Fraser Government went out of office in March 1983. In the period from March 1983 up to the present the minehunter inshore program has been funded by this Government. It admits to a loss of about $102m. When one talks to people in the Navy one learns the real loss is in excess of $160m. Most of that loss, probably better than 95 per cent, is a consequence of the lack of administrative control and surveillance by this Government on a program that simply was not working right at the outset.

The way the minehunter program has gone on, dragging money out of the taxpayer with no possibility of return at all, is, in my judgment, absolutely scandalous. It is still going on: tens of millions of dollars are still being spent on the minehunter program even though it has failed. The Government knows that, and it is going out to buy a totally different platform—a totally different ship and a totally different sonar system.

One of the other types of equipment that this Government has got into is the light armoured vehicle—the LAV25—about which quite a lot of information was advanced at the Estimates Committee a couple of months ago. It is something that was never researched, something that was never in the program. It was a spontaneous purchase by Mr Beazley because he liked the vehicles when he saw them in America a couple of years ago. We had a $25m buy initially to test these vehicles. When they came on test, they failed pretty well every element of the test that the Army gave them. Yet the Government is still going ahead and committing hundreds of millions of dollars to buy them.

The tests on this vehicle showed that in the area of its operation in the Northern Territory its tyres could not cope with the off-road conditions. It bogged in wet weather. It could not be used in summer because, with internal temperatures in excess of about 45 degrees centigrade, it was quite uninhabitable. It did not have the design strength to cope with the loads of personnel and weapons that the Army has to put in it. In other words, in every sense, that vehicle is a lemon. It does not meet any standards set at all, yet the Government is going ahead to buy it.

I would like to talk about the AEW&C aircraft, the airborne early warning and control aircraft, that Senator Ray talked about. I have been in the Senate for nearly 14 years. I am pleased to see Senator Tate in the chamber because he will recall very well that 12 years ago in the old Parliament House I spent quite a lot of time talking about the purchase of the new tactical fighter aircraft and radars. He would still remember interjecting on side lobes when I was talking about radar propagation.

Part of the argument for the new tactical fighter led me to the need for an AEW&C aircraft. I have been talking about that in this Parliament for over 12 years. It is quite dishonest, with the greatest of respect, for the Minister to say, `We cannot buy that now because the technology will be out of date'. There have been AEW&C aircraft since the mid-1940s. In time everything is superseded by later developments. To say that we will not buy these aircraft because the technology is not fully developed is to show a total lack of understanding of the technology that is currently available and, more importantly, of the essential need for this capability within the Australian Defence Force.

I will take on the Minister on that point. Were I the Defence Minister I would go out straightaway and start a program to purchase AEW&C aircraft for this country. I would get DSTO and a prime contractor overseas, in a partnership agreement, to do the developmental research so that we would have a system applicable to the conditions that we have in Australia, which are quite different from those in the NATO theatre for which most AEW&C aircraft are optimised.

To tell the Senate that we cannot buy these aircraft yet because the technology is not fully refined is to mislead the Senate. We need this capability, and we need to start working on it now. Even if we started working on it now, it would probably be eight to 10 years before that capability would be in service.

Finally, I just want to go back to where I started and to say that the 26 minutes that we had from Senator Ray was purely a political attack on the Opposition; it lacked any substance at all. We will go to the Australian people at the next election giving guidelines and pointing to the directions where we want to go with the Australian Defence Force. Very clearly, we want to give members of the Australian public very much better value for their dollar than they are getting at present. The whole burden of what Senator Ray was saying was: `I am perfect; I am a perfect administrator; I am getting you 110c for every $1 I spend. No-one can hold up any critical approach to me and say that he or she can do it cheaper and better'. That is absolute nonsense. In the expenditure of almost $10 billion per year, it can be done better. If, as Minister, I could not pick up $200m in savings by being a bit more efficient and producing exactly the same outcomes as we have at present, I would resign not only as Minister but also from the Parliament.
