TALK.START.PARA: —I want to participate briefly in this debate mainly to correct some of the straight, factual errors that peppered the whole of Senator Ray's remarks in this discussion. I start by fully supporting the final remarks of my colleague Senator MacGibbon, who echoes the whole view of the coalition in relation to value for money in defence. Anyone who says that there is no scope for more efficient and more effective value for money—better value for the defence dollar than now exists—obviously does not understand anything at all about the defence forces or, indeed, the public sector as a whole.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's proposals contained in the Fightback! document, which really have prompted this discussion today, are not about saving money just for the sake of saving money. Certainly, as far as Defence is concerned, they are not about less defence; they are about more defence, better defence and more efficient defence. If this Government has given away any thought of attempting to achieve greater efficiency in our defence forces and better value for money, then it is yet another mark of what is increasingly seen as a disintegrating government—a very old, tired government with no ideas at all.

Let me also say at the outset that I take great offence at the implication in Senator Ray's remarks that somehow or other the Australian Labor Party and Labor governments have a more intrinsic and more important view of defence than do the Liberal and National parties. The whole history of Australia has been wrought and littered with the failure by the Labor Party and Labor governments to give proper and appropriate support to defence. Throughout history they have neglected the importance of a strong, efficient Defence Force. Therefore, I refute Senator Ray's imputations as sheer humbug and hypocrisy.

I will now refer to some of the particular points of detail that Senator Ray mentioned. He has had at his disposal all the resources of government and has had three weeks to come up with something meaningful and accurate by way of comment on the coalition's Fightback proposals. Today he put out some statement while at a luncheon with journalists. I do not know what the statement was; we have not seen it. I know that it will be subjected to the most stringent examination by the coalition when we get it. It is amazing that it has taken three weeks, as I recall, for Senator Ray to make a response of any nature to the Fightback proposals for defence.

What staggers me is that, having taken all that time and having had all the resources of government at his disposal, he still got it absolutely wrong. I do not know whether Senator Ray has read the document. To give him the benefit of the doubt, I hope he has not read it. If he has read the document and made the crass elementary errors that he has made, then he had better go back to school because he will have completely misread the document. He rabbited on for a lengthy period about the amount of money that was going to be saved in net terms as a result of the Fightback proposals. Somehow or other he came up with a figure of $450m. That is simply wrong.

Table 16.1, on page 230 of the Fightback! document, is a summary of the proposed three-year expenditure program. The table has three columns; it is very easy to read. The first column is headed, `Increases in Outlays', the second column is headed, `Decreases in Outlays' and the third column is headed, `Net Savings'. With respect to defence, the first column shows that there is a $300m increase in outlays; the second column shows that there is a $500m decrease in outlays; and the third column shows that there are net savings of $200m. I do not understand how Senator Ray could possibly have got that wrong.

Table 16.2, on the very next page, shows the expenditure savings by year for each of the three years. We have shown that in the first year there would be an increase in outlays of $100m, a decrease of $150m; in the second year there would be an increase of $200m in outlays, a decrease of $350m; and, in the third year, nil either way, giving a net savings figure of $200m. What we are talking about could not be clearer than that. I just do not understand how Senator Ray got that so wrong.

In a document which was released by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) a couple of days ago, the Department of Finance made some comments on defence. I am not sure whether the Department got it wrong but, in reading its remarks, it looks as though it may have. The Department said—as I read its prose—that it considers the savings proposed by the coalition to be feasible and that they could be accommodated within the defence portfolio, but with some impact on capability in early years. I do not know what that means; the Department has not spelt that out. Perhaps, in due course, Senator Ray might come back and tell us what it means. The Department of Finance has said that the savings are feasible; it has not, in any shape or form, found any hole in the proposals from an arithmetic point of view—or any other point of view, for that matter—so far as it relates to virtually everything in the coalition's proposals, including defence.

Senator Ray also went on at considerable length about how we could achieve the gross savings of $500m which we are proposing over the three-year period. He implied that all of that money would be saved as a result of getting rid of people. Our proposals certainly envisage a reduction in personnel. That is quite clear; we have made no secret of that. But we have not said at any time that all of the gross savings would occur in that way. I refer to the report of the Auditor-General on fraud in the Defence Department. It is a very important document. I wonder whether Senator Ray has read it. It points to considerable fraud occurring in Defence; therefore, considerable savings are to be made with better fraud control. Page 249 of the Fightback! document states:

SPEECH.PARA: A more rigorous approach to capital equipment cost management will yield savings.

I wonder whether Senator Ray thinks no savings are possible there. I would find it strange if he did say that. My colleague Senator MacGibbon referred to the inshore minehunter project—this is spelt out on page 249 of our document. The project was cancelled in May 1991, but only after some $95m had been spent on developing prototypes which did not meet specifications. In the 1991-92 Budget—the current Budget—a further $13m has been allocated to the project, despite the earlier cancellation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the fraud investigation.

—As my colleague Senator Newman points out, the fraud investigation was very relevant to that too. There is considerable scope for savings by a better and more professional approach, and perhaps a little more ministerial attention to the activities of the Defence Department in the area of capital equipment and cost management.

PARA.TAB: The press release that Senator Durack put out today followed the release, at long last—for the first time—by the Government of some of the overheads involved in defence activities. These were contained in the commercial support manual recently released by the Department of Defence. That shows very easily how savings could be made in overheads, again, without necessarily touching on the question of levels of employment. We are not resiling from some reduction in employment levels.

There are various ways in which the savings of $500m over the three-year period can and will be achieved. If Senator Ray is saying that that is not achievable, then I can only say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he really is not trying in his job and he should not be there.

We then come to a couple of real furphies. Senator Ray set up the greatest straw man that I have ever heard set up in this Parliament. He went on for about five minutes about what would happen if the Government had to pay GST, or there had to be some sort of GST compensation. I kept telling him that it would not pay GST. He said, `It's not in your document'. I said, `It is in the document'. He said, `Where is it?'. I could not answer him at the time because I had the document in my office. I now have the document with me and—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should always carry it with you.
—I carry Fightback! everywhere with me; it just so happened that I left the supplementary papers behind for two seconds. It was the first time ever and will be the last time ever.

PARA.TAB: I refer Senator Ray to pages 15 and 16 of supplementary paper No. 5 of Fightback!. If he or some of his acolytes had taken the time to read this document; if he had used some of the resources of the Public Service, which were at his unlimited disposal at taxpayers' expense to try to knock holes in this thing; and if they had half a brain and had read the technical manual on the GST, they would have read section 5.4.3, which deals with supplies by public sector bodies. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The public sector is taxable if the goods or services are provided in the course of commercial activity.
Goods and services are zero-rated—
that means that they pay no GST on their input and no GST on their output—
if they comprise a regulatory activity or are non-commercial in nature, for example. . .
It lists a number of examples. The last example is:
governmental services like defence, law and order.

I refer Senator Ray to page 16 of supplementary paper No. 5 of the Fightback package. I hope that he will have the courtesy and the decency to come back into this chamber at some stage, admit that he set up the greatest straw man of all time and apologise to everyone who heard him make that absolute furphy.

PARA.TAB: The next absolute furphy of Senator Robert Ray came in his reference to redundancies. The coalition has provided $200m by way of provision for redundancy payments; we do not know whether that will be required, and we do not think it will all be needed but, on all reasonable calculations, it is a very generous estimate. Senator Robert Ray said that Defence and Industrial Relations were excluded from this redundancy payment. I have news for the Minister. He is again wrong.

I do not know which bit of the Fightback! documents the Minister has misread; I can only assume that he has confused redundancy payments with the exclusion—which is an exclusion, and it is specifically stated in the documents—of Defence and Industrial Relations from the 10 per cent cut in corporate services of government departments. We have done that because, as we have spelt out very carefully in the document, we have treated Defence differently: we say there is scope for administrative and related savings of 10 per cent across the board in the Department of Defence and therefore we excluded Defence from another 10 per cent cut in the corporate services area in order to prevent double counting—in other words, to prevent any conceptual hole at all appearing in the package. I assume that is the basis for Senator Ray's error, but I repeat that it is a totally elementary error. I hope that in due course Senator Ray will be big enough to come in here and admit that error.

I want to make a couple of comments on superannuation. I will not go into superannuation in any great detail, in view of the time and the fact that it is a very complicated subject. Let me just refute quite unequivocally the assertions that Senator Robert Ray made in relation to superannuation and whether they put any hole in the logic or the arithmetic of our proposals. They do not. I think it is another example of a complete misunderstanding. I hope it is just a misunderstanding and not a deliberate misrepresentation by the Minister. He is not that sort of person normally.

In relation to Defence superannuation, the coalition has always recognised that the Defence Force superannuation schemes are very different from normal superannuation schemes, and for very important policy reasons—that we need to have a superannuation scheme in relation to the defence forces that is in tune with the need for a young, fit, vigorous Defence Force. For that reason, the provisions in Defence Force superannuation schemes have always been different from normal superannuation schemes in various respects. That is a subject for a different day, but I think it is important to make that point here and now. I completely refute everything that Senator Ray said in that respect.

I have always had a pretty high regard and respect for Senator Ray. I think he normally does his homework and does a pretty good job relative to some of the other characters on the other side of the chamber. It is unusual for Senator Ray to make elementary errors at all, but it is almost unbelievable that he could have made the number of elementary errors that he did in his statement today. I can only assume that he has other, more pressing, weightier matters on his mind. I do not know where he has gone for his latest appointment. I do not know whether he has gone to do the tap on the shoulder or whether he is still doing the number counting before he does that, but he was obviously very distracted from his normal ministerial responsibilities today. Hopefully, that is the reason for his crass errors. Perhaps he will get his mind back on the job before too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is just one matter that Senator Short raised, no doubt in the enthusiasm of the debate, which ought to be corrected, because it is broadcast day. PARA.TAB: The Minister made a very long speech during Question Time about the additional costs he would have to pay on electricity. I think he said he would have to pay an increase of something like $52 on his electricity bill because of the effects of the GST. I do not accept that figure, but I want to point out to the Senate that Senator Collins, just on his fuel bill alone, will save some $400 per year because of the complete abolition of the fuel excise.

This particularly benefits those of us who live in northern Australia. Because of where we live we use our vehicles much more than people in the cities. We have longer distances to drive. The cost of fuel is enormous in northern Australia. The complete abolition of the fuel excise and its replacement for private motorists by the GST will mean fuel will be 19c per litre cheaper for everyone using his or her motor vehicle. Senator Collins well knows—and I am glad he has come into the chamber—that that is particularly significant for those of us who live in northern Australia.

If one happens to be in business, if one happens to rely upon freight to get one's goods to these more remote areas, the 26c per litre excise will be gone and the GST will be rebated in full. That will mean an enormous saving, which makes things so much easier for those of us living in the bush and in northern Australia.

Senator Collins made great play on his air conditioner. He is lucky enough—wealthy enough—to be able to afford one. Of course, many people have air conditioners in north Queensland. Payroll tax will be abolished, which will have very big benefits to northern Australia. Personal income tax cuts will be particularly significant. There are big improvements in the GST package for children in isolated areas, particularly those living in northern Australia, where many have to rely on assistance with education. Mr Hawke comes to north Queensland, northern Australia, once a year or thereabouts—it is not much more than that. Every time he comes he is asked about the zone tax rebate. The zone rebate was very important. It was introduced to try to compensate in some way those people living in remote Australia for the additional costs that might have been imposed. Dr Hewson has recognised this. He has taken positive steps in a one-off increase of 25 per cent and with a promise to properly look at it, properly reassess the boundaries and properly do the job to try to compensate people living in remote and regional Australia when he gets into government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill. This Bill amends the Australian Institute of Health Act 1973 to add to the existing functions of the Institute and to provide for a name change to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. The Institute was established in 1984 as part of the Department of Health. In 1987 it was established as a statutory authority. The Opposition opposed the move to its being established as a statutory authority because we felt that such a move was unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: The functions of the Institute were to research a wide range of health issues, with a particular focus on public health, social medicine, health statistics and health economics. The Bill before the Senate adds to the existing functions of the Australian Institute of Health. The new functions will include welfare functions as outlined in clause 4(d), functions such as: collecting, with the agreement of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and, if necessary, the Bureau's assistance, welfare related information and statistics; producing welfare related information and statistics; coordinating the collection and production of welfare related information and statistics by other bodies or persons; providing assistance for the collection and production of welfare related information, and so on. That clause outlines the new functions. The health functions of the Institute will remain unchanged.

The Bill will enable the Australian Institute of Health to take on the role of developing national welfare statistics focusing on the development, establishment and maintenance of national data sets relevant to policy planning and service delivery functions. The welfare statistics have only been collected on an ad hoc basis by various departments. The Bill also provides that the Minister, before giving directions to the Australian Institute of Health, must consult with the chairperson and the relevant State or Territory health, welfare or housing Minister. I understand that health and welfare Ministers have agreed that a memorandum of understanding will be developed jointly between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories outlining the rights and responsibilities of all parties in relation to the Institute's expanded role.

These changes have arisen as a result of an agreement by the Special Premiers Conference. Continuing consultation will occur between the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and the relevant State or Territory Minister. However, I note that the Bill removes nominees of the Public Health Administration of Australia and the Consumers Health Forum from the board of the Australian Institute of Health. I would be interested to hear from the Minister representing the Minister for Health, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), why this is so and what consultation, if any, took place regarding these changes.

The only justification given for the removal of these nominees from the board has been to keep the size of the board to a manageable level. I do not believe this is a justifiable reason. I certainly do not believe that it is excusable not to notify organisations that their positions on the board have been removed. In the committee stage of the Bill I foreshadow that I will be moving a number of amendments on behalf of the Opposition relating to the composition of the board of the Institute.

It is same old story with this tired old Government. It does not consult. When it comes to the health portfolio, it does not matter whether we are dealing with pharmacists, general practitioners, physiotherapists, radiologists, pathologists or people working in nursing homes. The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, will know that in this chamber we have been through Bills that have related to every one of those professions and that the constant complaint from every group is that the Ministers—the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples)—do not consult. That is the common complaint. Whichever group of health professionals or groups with an avid interest in the changes that relate to them we look at, there is inevitably no consultation. In this Bill there is no difference. A small Bill which should have zipped through this chamber comes across again as a failure of the Government due to Minister Howe, in this case, and his officers and Department not consulting.

I do not understand why Ministers in health-related portfolios are so confrontational. If they were not, we would see a greater level of cooperation with the health professionals and the health related groups, and surely Australians would be better served by an approach of proper consultation. Surely we would get better outcomes if those departments and those responsible Ministers consulted with the relevant groups. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: An allocation of $710 000 was made in the 1991-92 Budget to cover the cost of the enhancement of the Institute's role. This will increase to $1 670 283 in 1992-93, and $1 744 589 in 1993-94.

There is a good argument that the Institute should be part of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I do not mean that it should be subsumed by the Bureau, but that it should be an arm of it, concentrating on the collection, publication and so on of health, welfare and housing statistics.

PARA.TAB: There is some concern about the possible duplication of resources and the possible costs as a result. It is interesting to examine the role of the Australian Institute of Health vis-a-vis that of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The functions of the ABS as set out in section 6(1) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . constitute the central statistical authority for the Australian Government and, by arrangements with the Governments of the States, provide statistical services for those Governments.

The functions of the ABS are set out clearly there. Page 3 of the explanatory memorandum notes the expanded role of the Australian Institute of Health in relation to the role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It says:

The expansion of the Institute's role into welfare statistics needs to be considered in relation to the role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). That organisation is responsible for the coordination of all national statistics in Australia—

subject to overall coordination by the ABS with respect to health statistics and welfare statistics. I have shortened that, but generally that is the meaning of the explanatory memorandum. It is probably helpful to clarify the role of the AIH and the ABS. The explanatory memorandum says the Institute:
. . . advises ABS on the health statistics to be collected and published by the Bureau. In general, the Institute is not involved in the original collection of data.
It goes on to say the Institute:
. . . consults with the ABS on development of statistical standards and classifications relevant to health and health services.
As a result of this Bill, the explanatory memorandum says:

. . . the Institute will be responsible for the development, coordination and production of national statistics relating to welfare services and housing assistance. The ABS will retain responsibility for the coordination and production of statistics relating to the general well-being of the Australian population. The Institute will consult with the ABS on development of statistical standards and classifications relevant to welfare services and housing assistance.

It does not really matter what the outcome of the discussion about the roles of the Institute and the Bureau is. The main point is the importance of health statistics, no matter who collects them and disseminates them. The basic thrust of the Bill before us is to expand the Institute's role into welfare statistics. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services said in his second reading speech:
The need for national welfare statistics has been recognised for many years.

Major reports calling for the development of national welfare statistics have included the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1975, the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty in 1975, the Bailey Task Force on Coordination in Welfare and Health in 1976 and the Baume report on evaluation in Australian health and welfare services from the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in 1979.

PARA.TAB: It is for these reasons that the Opposition supports the Bill. I would be interested to know whether the Australian Institute of Health has done any work on the level of bulkbilling and the incidence of overuse and overservicing. Audit report No. 32, 1990-91, found that the areas with the highest growth in medical outlays are those with the highest proportion of bulkbilling. But the Government dismissed the evidence by claiming that the Department had tried to mirror the results, could not do so, and said they were invalid. One does not have to look far to see the abundance of evidence that proves that bulkbilling leads to overuse and overservicing. I would be pleased to know whether the Institute sees it as its responsibility and, if so, whether it would undertake a study—if it has not already done so—on this subject. It would be very interesting to see the Minister and the Department dismiss the evidence that it produced.

I advise the Minister that the coalition will be supporting the general thrust of this Bill, although we will have some amendments in the committee stage. I move the following second reading amendment:

At end of motion, add ", but given the overwhelming evidence of a direct link between bulkbilling and the overuse and oversupply of medical services, the Senate congratulates the Coalition parties for adopting a health policy in its `Fightback' proposals which abolishes bulkbilling except for pensioners, health care card holders and people with disabilities".

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the debate on the Sales Tax Amendment Bill (No. 3) I was encouraged to speak about the Opposition's health policy and was urged to restrain myself because there was only faint relevance, but with that amendment by Senator Patterson I think I am licensed to go, am I not? But the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) should not worry, I will try not to go on this issue, except to say, of course, that I will be loud in my protestations about the virtues of such an amendment. I will be loud in opposing that addition, and I probably do have the opportunity now to state a number of reasons why I should not congratulate anybody who thought up the Hewson package.

PARA.TAB: I turning firstly to the substance of the legislation, the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991. It is a very interesting and timely piece of legislation which indicates that we are looking at ways to further the collection, analysis and publication of the statistics so critical, not only in the field of welfare services and housing assistance, but also in the area of health.

Those who have read the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, which I chaired, entitled What Price Care? would know that we raised the difficulties associated with health statistics. One statistic which is often waved around this place relates to the curious problem of the number of people on public hospital waiting lists for elective surgery. It is still very difficult to get an accurate fix on how many people are on those waiting lists. This is a concern that shows how important this legislation and the amendment are. It is another justification for the establishment of the Institute of Health.

If the Commonwealth Government is to contribute funds to the States to enable them to provide services to the Australian people, the States need to be accountable. We need to know whether adequate services are being provided to public hospitals to enable them to meet the needs of those who need elective surgery. It is easy to come in here and, with very little evidence, wave bits of paper and insist that there are 100,000 people on waiting lists at public hospitals around Australia. There is certainly considerable evidence that those figures are, at best, very rubbery.

If one looks at the Opposition's health policy, one finds that the Opposition has now assessed that 60,000 people are on waiting lists. That is a remarkable drop. The Opposition is saying that in two years of this Government there has been a reduction of 40,000. In the run-up to the 1990 election the Opposition said that there were 100,000 people on the waiting list. Minister Blewett, who was the Minister for Community Services and Health at the time, did argue that in fact there were, by more accurate reckonings, 70,000 on the waiting lists. The Opposition and particularly Mr Shack were made to feel very stupid about their health policy in particular because of that error and that outrageous and unsubstantiated claim.

As I pointed out, the Opposition declares that the waiting list figure is now 60,000. That figure is still no more accurate than it was before, because we still cannot conclude precisely that 60,000 is an accurate assessment. We can say that it is more likely to be 60,000 or 70,000 than 100,000. I think there is now an agreement that the number of people on hospital waiting lists is not 100,000, as was claimed by the Opposition until so recently. Certainly, the Opposition's policy now claims that the figure is 60,000. So it is encouraging that we have at least been able to bid down the number of people on waiting lists.

Senator Patterson pointed out the importance of obtaining hard data in the area of health statistics, particularly hospital statistics. I concur entirely with that point. If we are to move to a case mix in hospital care, we need to recognise that the equations are very complex and difficult. As a result, we will have to analyse hard statistics that will need to be provided by hospitals. For example, private hospitals contribute very little towards the cost of educating nurses, allied health professionals, medical undergraduates, recent graduates and post-graduates.

Education costs make up part of the outlays of large public hospitals but they form almost no part of the outlays of a private hospital. I understand that some private hospitals are now becoming involved in some medical and nursing teaching but it is a modest sum compared with the contribution made by large public hospitals. If we were to undertake a case mix comparison on the cost of performing an appendectomy in a public hospital compared with the cost in a private hospital, we would need to take into account such things as the education costs of that public hospital.

We also have to take out a number of other things. Very few private hospitals, for example, have a morgue. Properly, we would not want every hospital in the country to have a morgue—for both the grim factors and an oversupply of unnecessary services. A number of other things have been and continue to be provided by public hospitals: for example, a toxic waste incinerator. Those are some of the areas of service provision that need to be properly assessed or accurately quantified so that they can be removed from the case mix equation. After we do some of that, we might then be able to make a more accurate assessment of costs. For all of those reasons, I entirely agree that the importance of adequate health statistics is a vital concern to the country.

Of course, we support the original legislation and these amendments. The amendments do not do much by way of extending the data for health statistics, but I do not mind taking the opportunity to argue their justification. It is important that we see the inclusion of welfare and housing assistance statistics in such an institute—a significant, reliable, recognised institute of data of the sort that can only be of assistance to the community and to government in the planning and the funding that is necessary to see adequate, appropriate, proper and, I would also add, equitable provision of services to people of this community.

The substance of the legislation is fine. I do not think there will be much dispute by anybody in this chamber about the significance of this legislation and there will be, I should have thought, large support for it. What seems to be the point of disagreement is how the board of this new Institute, if we are to call it a new institute, shall be constituted. In the committee stage, I will be moving amendments that have been circulated in this place in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —In your name? I don't have them.

—I am delighted that Senator Walters says that because I made sure they were circulated in this chamber yesterday, if not early this morning, and most of my colleagues have them. If Senator Walters does not have them, I would hope that we can provide them for her straightaway. They have certainly been around. They are provided in my name—they are Government amendments—and they go to ensuring that consumer representation is maintained on the board of the institute.

—On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to clarify the matter so that I can follow Senator Crowley's speech. When she refers to amendments in her name, does she mean in her name or in the name of the Government? I have Government amendments, but if she has some in her name I do not have them.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Walters, the amendments I have say that they are amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government by Senator Crowley in the Committee of the Whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do appreciate that it is not usual. I understand that it is not without precedent, but I am sorry if that has caused confusion for the Opposition. It is because I, like Opposition senators, am concerned that there is consumer representation on this Institute, as indeed is the Government. I am appreciative of Minister Tate for allowing these amendments on behalf of the Government to be moved in my name and, indeed, we have discussed that. It may be, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I will need your assistance in actually getting it right when the time comes to do it all.

PARA.TAB: It is very critical, if we are to have the collection of data of the sort that gives governments in particular the evidence with which they then justify a significant allocation of funding to service provision—that service provision now extending to the welfare and housing areas—that we have adequate consumer representation on that board, not just in an advisory capacity as was proposed but also at the actual decision making level. We all know the difference between being advisers and being decision makers. I do not think that needs to be argued in this place. It is also quite clear that the significance of a consumer voice is sometimes lost but, indeed, it ought to be guaranteed.

We are now facing in this place an agreement, I suspect, that consumer voices should be heard at the board level and that consumers ought be on the board. What we now have to deal with—I think Senator Lees and Senator Patterson will agree—is what we define as a consumer, because the consumer has gone from being a representative of the users or consumers of health services as, for example those represented by the Consumer Health Forum or ACOSS, a body that is reputable and a long recognised speaker on behalf of the people involved with welfare. I refer also to similar and allied housing institutions on behalf of users of housing, representatives of the AMA, the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospital Association.

Some might properly argue that hospitals are great consumers of health dollars. Indeed, they certainly are. I do not have a dictionary right to hand, but I understand that most of us would know what we mean by a consumer and we would not, first of all, think that a consumer meant a relevant professional organisation. They may be properly involved in the collection and provision of statistical data, but I do not believe that they would be, in any common understanding, defined as consumers.

I think the case put by the Australian Hospital Association and the Australian Private Hospital Association for one or other of those two to have a representative on the board is not without some power because I take the point that hospitals are going to be very significant players in the health statistics. Indeed, I have just made that case in terms of case mix or hospital waiting lists. It is interesting that if we go this way we may find a large number of the funds directed towards how many dollars of the health budget are allocated to hospitals. It is a very significant amount, and quite clearly hospitals could argue the case that they should have a say in what kind of data is collected, how much, and so on.

It could also be the case though, that, as such an amount is consumed by hospitals and there is such a need for data about the health of the community and the provision of services outside of hospitals, we may even see a case arguing for representatives of public health services, representatives of general practitioners who provide services outside of hospitals, and so on. I think a very good case could be made for that if one wanted to argue that way; but I do not find it convincing. The fact that hospitals are going to be critically part of health statistics does not justify the representation on the board of either the Australian Private Hospital Association or the Australian Hospital Association. It is my understanding at this time that they would not be what I would call a consumer, nor what the Government would call a consumer. But I am not quite sure what will be finally concluded on that matter. I would want to argue that they are not commonly known as consumers. But in arguing that they should not be included under the heading of consumer representation on the board, I would hope no-one would be overlooking such organisations in collecting the data, and the close negotiation with them would certainly be part of any valid institute work.

But we cannot afford to have included, on a functioning board, people who would have some valid claim for their area of involvement in the provision of health services in this country; it would become unworkably large. What on earth would justify the AMA as apart from, for example, the College of General Practitioners? What on earth would justify the AMA as apart from the Doctors Reform Society or salaried medical officers? I do not believe we can start arguing for the AMA. If it were the case that we wanted to argue for one doctor representative for the medical profession, I think we could actually have a different sort of argument, but I do not believe that is the case.

I understand that the Opposition, whose amendments have only recently been provided, is proposing that there be a representative from the AMA. I argue that that is not a representative group of medical practitioners. The AMA has a wonderful history of being particularly able to state its own case. It is now widely recognised that the AMA does not speak for many doctors in this country. It certainly does not speak for the salaried medical officers, who have their own union and their own representatives.

The Bill should be amended in a general way and should not restrict consumers by naming an institution and requiring that only representatives of that institution or organisation can provide a consumer representative from the areas of health, welfare, housing or a specific research area. On behalf of the Government, I will be moving an amendment to include representation of consumers of health services, welfare services, housing assistance services and consumers with research ability. We are making sure that those consumer voices will be heard on the board level, where the decisions are being made. That is a point on which we are in agreement with the Opposition.

I do not believe that the Government is minded to support either hospital or the medical representation, as proposed by the Opposition. I think they will best represent themselves by collecting statistics and data in a sensible way. It makes good sense for people in the health arena not to overlook public and private hospitals or the Australian Medical Association when collecting the necessary statistics and evidence under this Bill.

I think the same applies in the areas of welfare and housing, both of which are new areas. I shall certainly be watching very closely the consequences of bringing them under the one institute. I think it makes for a very large beast. I am a bit concerned that its largeness and the extension of its work may lead to a modification of the focus of its data collection. I would not like to see the health area watered down in any way or find that the welfare and housing statistics are insufficient because these areas have been brought together. I will be watching that very closely. My colleague Senator Patterson, who is across the chamber, is in agreement that we should watch this closely so that there is not insufficient collection of data under such a large institute, as this will no doubt become.

There is no doubt that we finally have recognition of the importance of the collection of this data at the national level and it promises significant and exciting possibilities. It needs to be watched very closely, because it will be very large. From the information we glean we may want to modify the way the Institute is designed in the future. We would like to know how it meets its task or the difficulties it confronts, if any. All that being said and agreed, in large part, our problem is to define a consumer, but consumer representation on that board is not in disagreement. I hope that in the course of the passage of the legislation we can agreeably work that out.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have noted, the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991 introduces a number of changes which expand the functions of the Australian Institute of Health enabling it to collect, analyse and publish statistics not only in the health area but also in the areas of welfare services and housing assistance.

PARA.TAB: Prior to this legislation, the institute's activities have been restricted to the health field, and the Government sees this expansion as the first step in developing and strengthening national welfare statistics. We certainly hope it is right in that. This change in the institute's role recognises the need for accurate and reliable national welfare data and, as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) noted when introducing the Bill, there have been several calls over the past 15 years for the development of a process to collect and analyse this sort of information.

This expansion comes at a time of significant change in the delivery of health, welfare, disability and housing services throughout the country. It gives the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, as it is now going to be known, a potentially vital role to play in the reform of Commonwealth-State relations. I do not think there is any dispute here of the fact that there is a very great need to collect statistics in these areas. If decisions with far-reaching consequences are going to be taken about the delivery of welfare and health services, then it is obvious that these must be based upon accurate information. There is also a need to evaluate the success or otherwise of ongoing programs and to determine whether or not the outcomes of programs are what we expect or, indeed, what we want.

All this sounds, and is, perfectly sensible, but much depends on whether the Government actually takes any notice of the data that is collected by the Institute. We would all agree—certainly some of us on this side of the chamber—that this Government has been particularly good at setting up projects to collect and analyse data, at considerable expense to the taxpayer, and then totally ignoring the data that has been collected if its implications do not support what the Government is proposing to do.

A prime example of this technique that exists at the moment is the national health strategy which the Government—in particular, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe—has done a great job of ignoring, despite its being the most comprehensive analysis of the health system ever undertaken in this country. There is the Australian Institute of Family Studies, a body that consistently turns out excellent statistical and analytical work only to see its funding base eroded year after year and its findings ignored.

Another issue is whether or not enhancing the role of the Institute is necessarily the best way to go about collecting national welfare statistics. I know views have been expressed in some quarters that strengthening the role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics may have been a better way to go. However, I do not want to canvass those issues at this point in time and I will not be pursuing them.

In general, we welcome the new role for the Institute. It is highly desirable that we collect and understand data about child-care services, particularly in relation to the welfare of children; aged care services; services for people with disabilities; and housing needs. There has been an absence of quality national statistics in these areas for quite some time. I see the Institute's new tasks as being a very positive step in developing and understanding welfare and housing needs and the needs particularly for specific service delivery.

As has been noted by previous speakers, the one major concern we all have about this Bill is the change in the composition of the board. Until now, there have been 12 members of the board consisting of the chairperson; the Director of the Institute; three members nominated by the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, that is, the State and Federal health Ministers; the Australian Statistician; the Secretary of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services; three members nominated by the Minister—and, at present, these are two academics, Peter Scotton and Bettina Cass, and a senior journalist, Gay Davidson; a member nominated by the Public Health Association; and a member nominated by the Consumers Health Forum.

These last two organisations have represented the interests of consumers and community-based service providers in the health area. Under this legislation as it stands, these two organisations have been dumped from the board and I think we must ask the Minister, when we get into the committee stage of this Bill, why this has been done. I might add that when my office rang the Consumers Health Forum and the Public Health Association seeking their views on the Bill, both organisations told us that they had yet to be formally advised by the Minister or his Department of the decision to remove them from the board, although I understand their representatives did have an idea that it was a possibility—they were aware of discussions—and it was a possibility that they had vigorously opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't surprised, were you?

—No, I was not, because unfortunately this failure to consult key interest groups is something that we have been coming across time and time again. Indeed, in a number of recent pieces of legislation that have passed through this chamber it became very apparent that there had been no significant discussion with organisations which were adversely affected by the changes proposed. It represents political and bureaucratic arrogance, I suggest, of the most appalling kind. It is behaviour that should be challenged on every possible occasion.

PARA.TAB: In this instance, the two organisations concerned have taken seriously both their responsibilities on the board and their obligations to keep their members in touch with what is happening at the Institute. Dumping them off the board without even the courtesy of an advisory letter illustrates pretty clearly how highly the Minister rates community based service providers.

In this Bill, the Government is proposing a different board composition in accordance with the new role of the Institute. It was planned that the new board would consist of only 11 members: the chairperson; a director; one member nominated by the AHMAC; the Australian Statistician; the Secretary to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services; a representative of the State housing departments; a member nominated by the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators; three members nominated by the Minister; and a staff member of the Institute elected by the staff. Honourable senators should note that there is no provision for any community or consumer representation.

Yet, when we look at what the new look Institute will be doing, we see that many of its welfare related functions are likely to impact directly on service providers and that there surely will be a need for input and, indeed, as Senator Crowley noted, a need for decision making as the board comes to deal with its new functions—that is, decision making by those organisations which are most affected.

This new board is loaded with bureaucrats and persons with vested interests in following political and departmental agendas. Those agendas are frequently vastly different from the interests and agendas of consumers and service providers—especially those operating in the community or charitable sectors. In fact, in view of the nature of the new responsibilities the Institute has been given, there is a sound argument for not only retaining the existing level but also actually increasing community representation.

Before the Australian Democrats proposed amendments and enlisted the support of the Opposition, the Minister apparently had a number of excuses as to why he would not be continuing the practice of community representation on the Institute board. Firstly, he is apparently planning to set up an Australian Health and Welfare Information Council as an advisory body to the Institute. We were told that this would include various key organisations in the relevant fields.

Aside from the fact that the structure of this body is not finalised—we really do not have any details as to what is actually being proposed—it relegates the community sector to simply an advisory capacity, rather than its having any power or any say in the decision-making process. It ignores the importance of the presence of independent community based voices with direct responsibility on the Institute board.

The Minister claims that the new Council will have a vital input into the Institute's decision making processes, but there is certainly no legislative mechanism for that to occur. There is no guarantee that the Council will be anything more than a little side issue, a talk-shop, with absolutely no influence whatsoever over what the Institute actually does.

Another argument seemed to be that, if additional members were placed on the board, it would become too large and unwieldy. That is one argument I really cannot buy at all. For example, if one representative from each of the health, housing and welfare sectors were to be included on the board—which is what we are proposing—it would comprise 14 members. Even if all the foreshadowed amendments get up here today, the board will still have only 17 members. There are many private organisations, non-government, community based and corporate organisations which have 17 or more members on their boards and which function perfectly adequately. I fail to see why the Institute would experience any difficulty—especially when we weigh any possible difficulties against the advantages of having direct access to the views and expertise of those relevant sectors.

Another view that has been put forward is that it was not possible to fix upon one representative from each sector because of rivalries between organisations. I find that argument quite extraordinary. It is very clear to all that there are key peak bodies which are easily recognisable in each of the three sectors concerned. There may be rivalries and disagreements within those sectors, but surely it is up to the organisations in those fields to truly sort those matters out and to truly represent those sectors.

The Australian Democrats will be moving amendments to have a peak body from each sector nominate a member to the board. We are suggesting that those bodies should be the Consumers Health Forum in the health area; National Shelter in the housing area; and, of course, ACOSS in the welfare sector. I have discussed this Bill at length with Senator Patterson. I am very pleased that not only will the Opposition be supporting our amendments, but also Senator Patterson will be moving an amendment to ensure that the Public Health Association continues to be a member of the board.

We have put forward the Consumers Health Forum because we are satisfied that it has the broad-based membership necessary to fulfil the role of representing the community health sector. It has a long record of advocating on behalf of consumers in the health system. In addition, its membership covers a very wide spectrum of interests which enable it to look beyond the narrow `health only' focus—a view, I suggest, that will be crucial to the success of the Institute's new responsibilities.

ACOSS is obviously an appropriate choice for the board. Regardless of whether, at some points in time, the Opposition and the Government have disagreed with ACOSS's public views, I think all would agree that it is the peak body for the welfare sector and it is certainly well placed to provide input from a large range of service providers.

National Shelter is the peak body representing housing services. The community housing sector has particular concerns and issues that would best be addressed by specific representation. I would also point out that this organisation has taken an active and well informed interest in changing Commonwealth-State relations and their impact on housing assistance programs.

Here we must acknowledge the Australian Medical Association, which has had a major input into particular community health issues such as alcohol consumption and tobacco use. Given the nature of the Institute's work, I think it is important that, as the Association represents a significant group of primary service providers, it be given the opportunity to ensure that the Institute has access to a very extensive data collection base. As well, I believe the Association is in a position to alert the Institute to important basic primary health issues.

I note that Senator Crowley has some concerns with regard to the possibility of hospitals being represented, but in her speech she also noted particular issues relating to the hospitals and the fact that they have such a large percentage of the health budget in their corner. Therefore, I think it is appropriate, with the way we are now looking at restructuring and access from a wide variety of different points of view and different interests, that hospitals be included.We will see a board that has 17 members, and I do not believe that at any point in time that will be found to be in any way unworkable.

Although the Government initially found the Democrat proposals unacceptable, I understand that Senator Crowley, on behalf of the Government, is now putting up several amendments which, on their own, would ensure broader representation. I do have a certain amount of cynicism about these proposals, not least because I am well aware that the only reason they have been put up is that the Government has realised that our amendments will be successful, as will the Opposition amendments, and I believe the Government is now trying to salvage something out of it.

However, that is not the reason why I will be opposing them. I am simply not satisfied with the Government amendments. I think they are far too broad and I think they will give the Minister considerable discretion as to which group or which representatives of which group he accepts or does not accept from the nominations. I believe the amendments that the Democrats and the Opposition are putting forward will be less open to manipulation and, therefore, I would prefer to stick with those. The Democrats' amendments will assist in avoiding the Institute becoming just another bureaucratic exercise, operating to assist governments and departments, without having much to offer the very people its data collection is ultimately supposed to be benefiting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill because of the absolute nonsense that Senator Crowley spoke earlier. She is obviously making her bid for the health ministry in the new Keating Cabinet. I am not sure whether she belongs to the right faction or even, for that matter, the left faction, the centre faction or the inside out faction.
—The left right out.

—Yes; I am not certain where Senator Crowley stands. The rubbish that she spoke about representation was absolutely appalling. It shows that she is so far out, she probably will not be able to get back in again.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley spoke of the different representatives who should be on the board of this Australian Institute of Health. If we kept appointing people from particular interest groups, there would be more people in that Institute than there are in this building. I thought that we were the representatives of the people and that is why we are here, rather than putting on representatives from this group and that group.

As to Senator Crowley's argument about salaried doctors, specialists, general practitioners, public health doctors and so on, the fact of the matter is that more than 21,000 doctors are members of the Australian Medical Association. They actually pay about $500 to be members of that Association. As a generalisation, one-third are salaried doctors, one-third are general practitioners and one-third are specialists. So the AMA is an overall representative body.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Doctors Reform Society? How many of them are in private practice?

—The Doctors Reform Society claims to have 1,000 members. I am not certain they are all doctors. I am not certain how much they pay to become members or even that they pay at all. It is totally unrepresentative. The argument that the AMA does not represent doctors is totally spurious.

PARA.TAB: The other argument that Senator Crowley brought forward was to do with waiting lists and why the coalition has reviewed the figures. The fact is—Senator Crowley is correct in this—that it is difficult to quantify waiting lists. This Government has, by its differential lowering of rebates, stimulated the development of day surgery centres. In fact, in the past two years since those figures were tabulated by the Opposition, 46 free-standing day surgery units have been established in Australia which deal with minor surgery and have changed quite markedly the number of people kept on waiting lists.

Let us not think of the quantity; let us think of the qualitative aspects of waiting lists, of the people who are waiting for coronary bypass surgery at Prince Charles Hospital in Brisbane who have to wait so long that the mortality rate is increased. Let us think of the elderly patients who are waiting for more than two years at the Royal Brisbane Hospital for hip replacements, who are putting up with the pain and the problems associated with gross arthritic changes in their hips; the people who have been waiting longer for knee replacements and other joint replacements; or the people who are waiting for other major surgery. These people may not be large in number, but these waiting times represent immense personal agony and prolonged morbidity for the people who suffer from these diseases.

Finally, Senator Crowley was with me yesterday at the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health. Professor Bob Douglas has collated the responses of the 2,000 doctors from all over Australia who were asked to comment on the problems affecting general practice. They were not members of the AMA; they were not particularly members of the Doctors Reform Society. There were 2,000 doctors who took the trouble to reply to a questionnaire comprising 120 detailed questions, and those replies were analysed.

The thing that figured most was the necessity for the abolition of bulkbilling because this was seen as the major cause of the development of entrepreneurial clinics and the development of poor quality medicine in Australia. The second most important figure shown was the number of doctors who were practising in our community, again stimulated by Senator Crowley's Government because of the unrestricted entry of overseas trained doctors to the detriment of the ability of Australian children to go into medical schools here. Senator Crowley's Government has a lot to answer for. I believe that the amendment moved by the Opposition is to be commended because, at least by advocating the development of the Fightback proposals, the coalition's health policy goes a long way towards restoring quality in health care in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991, which is before us this evening, broadens the responsibility of the Australian Institute of Health. It extends the responsibility of the Institute, which was previously—and I quote from its objective—`to contribute to the pool of health knowledge which may be used to develop better strategies to improve the well-being of Australians'. Its responsibility has been extended by this Bill so that it will become the national welfare statistics collection centre.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Bureau of Statistics is already putting together this data. I believe that we could save the country a considerable amount of money. The appropriations for 1991-92 are nearly $5m. According to the financial impact statement before us, that will be increased by $1.75m. That is a considerable sum of money, and I wonder whether that is an appropriate way for us to go.

Senator Crowley has mentioned amendments to put consumer representatives on the board of this Institute. That will give consumers input into the Institute, but deny the medical profession any input at all. I believe that that is totally wrong. My colleague Senator Patterson will be moving amendments on behalf of the Opposition to include not only the AMA, but also one of the hospitals associations, which I believe would be of a great advantage.

Senator Crowley has said that the AMA should not be included. It was on the interim board of the Institute and it was taken off. Senator Crowley has said that it should not be on the board because, after all, the AMA does not represent doctors. She asks why other groups, such as the Doctors Reform Society, should not be on the board. I can explain to Senator Crowley the difference between the AMA and the Doctors Reform Society. As Senator Herron has already said, one-third of the AMA's members constitute the medical profession, and are paid members of hospital staff. The Doctors Reform Society claims that it has 1,000 members—it never tells us the exact number—and has primarily doctors who are paid members of hospital staff. I think there are only half a dozen members who have ever been in private practice. They are far less representative and are a very small group that could not possibly be considered to be representing the doctors.

Senator Crowley was extolling the virtues of Medicare. As Chairman of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, which looked at hospital costs and health insurance, she knows only too well that the evidence given to that Committee was that the number of people on waiting lists at that time was, I think, 75,000 in any one day for various things.

PARA.TAB: State hospitals are in dire trouble. Every honourable senator knows the problems that their State hospitals have in getting funds. The Government has continually knocked back or cut the money which goes to hospitals. We know that the Government has closed beds; we know how many vacant beds there are in public hospitals; we know that the capital expenditure has ceased; we know the dreadful state that the hospitals are presently in; we know that their equipment is at a disastrous level, that there is very little modern equipment; we know, as I have said, that the people are dissatisfied with it. The State hospitals try to cope with this lack of funding in a variety of ways.

I refer to a letter which was given in evidence to Senator Crowley's Committee. The letter explains how this particular hospital coped with the lack of funds and tried to provide some sort of service to its patients. The letter is sent by the Medical Director of Williamstown Hospital to the Executive Director, the Director of Nursing and the Admissions Clerk. The letter states:

The financial position of the Hospital has deteriorated throughout the month of January and the over-run is now in the order of $385,000.00 This amount has to be recovered before the end of the financial year. In particular, the Visiting Medical Officers' payments are presently $92,000.00 over budget with pathology and radiology payments also over budget. These over-runs reflect a private/public mix of 66.2% public patients to date—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, only 66.2 per cent public patients in that hospital to date. The letter continues:
an over-run of 6.2%. It is therefore necessary to adjust the number of public patients admitted for the balance of the financial year to the level budgeted for.
Obviously, that 66.2 per cent of public patients has to be brought down to 60 per cent, for the financial reasons of this public hospital. The letter continues:
In consequence—
just get a load of this!—

all future elective bookings of public patients will be on the basis that any number in excess of one public patient per elective list will require approval from the Medical Director. This restriction will not be introduced for patients for whom requests for admission have been received as of today the 23rd February, 1988 but will be active for all requests for admission received after today. The restriction will remain in place until future notice.

Because the public hospital had an over-run, because of its budget, because it had too many public patients, too many Medicare patients—that is, 66.2 per cent, instead of the budgeted 60 per cent—the Executive Director ordered that there be no more than one public patient on an elective surgery list until private patients were brought into the hospital to fill those elective lists. Is that not a dreadful situation? Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you would agree that public hospitals should be kept primarily for Medicare patients. But this hospital was able to cope with its funding under Medicare only if 40 per cent of its patients were private and thus paying. Is that not an appalling situation? The elderly, the pensioners and the poor had to be put off. The hospital allowed only one public patient —from among the poor, the pensioners, et cetera—per elective list. All the rest had to be private patients. That is how that particular hospital coped to try to get its funding. And we are told what a wonderful caring compassionate Government we have and how wonderful Medicare is for the poor! I have heard you, Mr Acting Deputy President, refer to it that way.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Do not bring me into it all the time. I am an unbiased chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am addressing you, Mr Acting Deputy President. PARA.TAB: What a dreadful situation we have reached. Is it any wonder that Medicare is now collapsing around our ears? Doctors now have to be squeezed out further and further and the Government has done away with bulkbilling. The Government has required a patient co-payment. Under our policy, we will expand that and entitle and encourage people to privately insure for their hospital treatment. An income of $25,000 a year is a relatively middle income. Mr Acting Deputy President, you show horror. We may not feel that in this place, but that is true. The average income is $30,000 a year. I am talking about a family on $25,000 a year. We will give that family $200 cash, if it wants it, to help it. How many low income earners or pensioners are privately insured?

Senator Crowley knows the answer because she was Chairman of the Committee. She knows that the priority for many pensioners is private insurance. We know that they will go without all sorts of things to privately insure because Medicare is not good enough for them. Medicare is not good enough for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his wife; they privately insure. It is not good enough for them, but it is all right for the rest of Australia. Medicare is not good enough for me. I certainly have private insurance and so have the majority of people who can afford it. PARA.TAB: This is a debate on the Australian Institute of Health Amendment Bill 1991. Whilst the focus of our attention in the chamber this evening has been quite narrow, on an institute which ought to be enabled to undertake the collection, analysis and publication of statistics in the fields of welfare services and housing assistance, I believe that the debate has ranged a little more widely than that, in particular because of the second reading amendment moved by Senator Patterson on behalf of the Opposition. The Government will not be supporting the amendment, particularly as it seems to find something noteworthy, something to be the subject of congratulation, in the idea of abolishing bulkbilling—the coalition policy—except for pensioners, health care card holders and people with disabilities. That proposal by the apostles of free choice would strip from general practitioners the ability to make decisions in regard to the way in which they conduct their practice, by which they may wish to offer a bulkbilling service to their patients, those who attend for primary health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a 15 per cent discount.

—If they wish to. What Senator Herron is doing as a member of a party which is given to the marketplace and to the idea of competition between various sectors, particularly in the provision of services, is taking away the capacity of some GPs to offer that competitive stimulus to the provision of medical services and health care to the Australian people. I find that quite remarkable.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron must also admit that the proposal is linked to the fact that his Party is encouraging people not only to pay, as they must, their Medicare levy, 1.25 per cent of their taxable income, but also to take out private insurance to cover the fee that they will pay for consultation with their GP, because that GP's fee will be set at the AMA schedule fee. Because there is no bulkbilling competition from GPs people will find that they will have to insure in order to be able to meet the $31 they will have to pay on the deal between the AMA and the private health insurance funds.

Of course, what the Opposition policy is about is the transfer of hundreds of millions of dollars to GPs from the pockets of patients who present themselves for primary health care and attention at their GP, using the AMA schedule fee, via the private health insurance funds. That is a simple description of what is proposed and therefore the Government will not be supporting the second reading amendment.

As I say, the reformation of the charter of the Australian Institute of Health is an important step in ensuring that we have an Australia-wide capacity, well supported by all governments—the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories—to collate necessary statistics in order to permit rational policy making so far as the provision and funding of services are concerned, whether it be in the health, welfare or housing fields. In fact, this is one of the very good results to come out of the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference, where the heads of government agreed that there would be great good served by the collation of such data Australia-wide—nationally consistent data—and the Australian Institute of Health will be given that expanded role. I believe that health and welfare Ministers, as recently as 6 September 1991, agreed on that expanded role.

I believe that we can have confidence in the Institute. It has already been involved in the development of a national minimum dataset for institutional health care, made progress towards a national health labour force data collection covering a number of health professionals, made progress towards a national cancer statistics clearing house and an inventory of Australian health data collections, and has initiated the development of a national health information agreement. That sort of track record gives us confidence in the capacity and the ability of the Institute to provide nationally useful statistics over the much wider area.

It is also very important to emphasise—and I know this is of particular and genuine interest to Senator Patterson—that, in the collection of welfare services and housing assistance data, privacy and confidentiality requirements must be met and will be met. The Institute's legislative framework—its statutory charter—already provides for the confidentiality of all such records, and of course there are no amendments to change or modify those particular provisions. They have proved to be adequate safeguards and they are certainly necessary. I am quite sure that the Parliament would not give to the Institute the tasks it is giving it without the assurance of those statutory safeguards and the knowledge that they have worked well to date.

Finally, some concern has been expressed about the proposed Institute board structure. I understand that all sides of the chamber now—including Senator Crowley—have made contributions to the debate in terms of there being a necessity for consumers' representatives or the representatives of various groups to find a place on the board, and the Government can see the merit in those proposals.

I know that Senator Lees and the Australian Democrats have consistently made these submissions, and there is merit in what they have put forward. I must say that I find greater attraction in Senator Crowley's proposals, for reasons that would perhaps be better expressed at the committee stage. I do believe that Senator Crowley made a very eloquent and sensible plea for the ability of the Minister to make available for the board, for the management of this Institute, a wider range of his or her ministerial nominees to provide for a much broader participation of those who have knowledge and might be affected by the collection of these statistics.

I believe that the Government will indicate its preferred support for Senator Crowley's amendment, but of course will be open to ensure that at the end of the committee stage there will be a proper representation from various groups that were nominated by Senator Crowley. In one way or another they should find a place on the board. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with the difficulty that I believe the Institute will confront, as I think has already been evidenced in the amendments circulated to this Bill; that is, representatives of special bodies, selected organisations, will be nominated directly to the board. That carries with it a necessary restriction on the groups from whom the nominations to represent consumers of health, welfare, housing, and public health research institutes can be drawn. I move this amendment because I believe it is of value not to specify a restricted list of organisations; secondly, to provide the prospect then of a wider group of people with the expertise—that is, to represent consumers—whose nomination could come from one or many bodies, from health, welfare, housing or public health research; and those names going through to the Minister allows the Minister to make a choice before making a nomination to the board. In this way I think we extend the range of people from whom the nomination can be drawn.

PARA.TAB: We give the Minister some options from whom he or she can make the choice. We also avoid the difficulty of listing particular organisations as the only organisations which can provide the nomination. I believe that is a very good policy because it is quite clear that in the not too distant future we could be assured that other bodies, properly constituted, properly representing consumer interests, will be clamouring for their place on this board. Why would we justify the representation from consumer group A and not consumer group B? We know consumer groups do emerge from time to time, validly constituted and properly representing consumer interests. I feel this amendment actually addresses the difficulty of restricting nominations to the board from specified organisations.

I believe this amendment will provide more options and a wider range of prospective talent for the board and will provide to the Minister the opportunity to make a selection from those nominations so that the board will be enriched by drawing from a wider base. We also avoid the trap of listing specified organisations and, therefore, de facto excluding any other organisation which may properly and validly provide the same kind of person, able to do the same kind of task and adequately represent consumers.

The change in the constitution of the Institute to include welfare and housing creates a very big challenge for the people on the board. They will have to make significant decisions about the research that will be done, the direction of the resources and the allocation of funds to one part of research as opposed to any other. I believe that the Institute, on behalf of consumers, will be more adequately served if the consumer representation is drawn from a wider, rather than a more restrictive, pool. For all those reasons, I argue the case for the amendment as written.

I also make the point that it does not include representation from the AMA, from any other doctors organisation or from the private or public hospitals arena. I commented on that in my speech during the second reading debate. I think the valid contribution that representatives from those organisations will make is undeniable. That is not the point. We are here looking at the representation on the Institute's board and the campaign—particularly the campaign that led to my amendment, I am sure Senator Lees's amendment, and very possibly Senator Patterson's amendment—by consumer groups for their continuing representation on a board—

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't even know they were left off.
