TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Bank Integration Bill 1991 is to enable the final processing of the removal of the distinction between savings banks and trading banks, which commenced with the Banking Legislation Act 1989. At the outset, in handling this Bill for the Opposition, I express very real concerns which, unfortunately, are held by a great many Australians about banks and the banking industry, about banking policies and practices, and about the need to set up a more rewarding banking environment for customers.

PARA.TAB: The failed, leaderless Hawke Labor Government is a captive of our nation's nineteenth century industrial culture. It has missed the chance to create history by its failure to break the mould of our sleepy industrial and commercial structures. While the Government cannot be held totally responsible for its inheritance, it must be blamed for not seriously tackling problems which have become blindingly obvious in the past decade, especially problems evident in the banking industry.

Such concerns have been reiterated only recently, with the tabling of the so-called Martin report on banking. The report, as predicted, made sweeping proposals to ensure that banks were more accountable to their customers and to expose them to more competition from foreign banks. The report was critical of all of the major banks for their involvement in foreign currency loans which, as we know, were a focal feature of the deregulated financial market during the last decade.

One of the conclusions of the report is that many of the banks have attempted to portray themselves as the compliant victims of borrowers determined to obtain foreign currency loans. This is difficult to accept because competition was a force driving banks to offer the loans, with the quality of bank advice on the risks being variable, depending on the experience and the judgment of bank staff.

One of the very real concerns which many individuals and business operators in this country have is the fear of bankruptcy. For many, it is not merely a financial issue; it is an emotional issue which conjures up images of stress, harassment, social disgrace and dishonour—and well it might be a concern in the disastrous economic environment created by this failed Labor Government.

The latest statistics for bankruptcy in our community highlight the extent of pain and suffering caused through bankruptcies under this destabilised and destabilising Government. On the 1991 September quarter figures, bankruptcies have increased by a staggering 72.2 per cent over the previous September quarter. They are up nearly 20 per cent on the 1991 June quarter. Between June and September of this year well over 4,700 people went broke, as if the 4,000-plus who went broke between March and June was not bad enough. In simple terms, this means that in just the last three months 4,764 extra families have been directly affected by bankruptcy—10 families every hour of the working day. Indirectly, thousands of employees and their families are now experiencing financial problems due to redundancies and retrenchments attributable to bankruptcies. The tragedy is that the worst is yet to come.

The Martin report has demonstrated a need for more rigorous supervisory regimes in this riskier lending environment. The Reserve Bank, as supervisor, needs to be more vigilant and have the appropriate tools to undertake the task. The Reserve Bank has clearly not been as alert as it should have been in relation to how deregulation had changed its role as supervisor of the banking industry. While more vigilance may somewhat reduce the number of bankruptcies, only a change to the economic environment—which will be initiated by a Liberal-National Party government—will have a sufficiently beneficial impact.

A little more than a year ago—at the outset of the Martin inquiry into banking—those involved in the uppermost levels of the banking industry must have felt that they were in for a lot more than a mere public flogging or even a diligent media going-over. The public perception of banks and banking then was unconditionally at an all-time low. Doubtless one of the growing numbers of ex-Treasurers, Mr Keating, saw it as very convenient timing to launch into an attack on banks when public antipathy for the industry was at its zenith. At least temporarily, the inquiry proved to be a sound diversionary tactic for the Labor Government and its former Treasurer to turn up the heat on the peril the industry was facing and away from the Keating-engineered recession that the country was uncontrollably sliding towards.

Unfortunately for the financial and banking sectors, public confidence has not improved a great deal since that time. With the collapse and demise of a number of Australian financial institutions—the South Australian State Bank, the State Bank of Victoria and the Pyramid Building Society, to name just a few—Labor governments, State and Federal, around Australia have completely lost the confidence of the people, while the banks still have to regain the confidence and trust of their customers.

Only the eviction of Labor from wherever it holds office can restore overall confidence. Let us hope that this transition occurs quickly because the changes which are still to take place should result in significant benefits to all Australians and to our economy. It is evident that a more responsive and innovative banking sector is emerging in the wake of financial deregulation. We also hope that many lessons have been learned from the banking industry's past mistakes.

There have been huge banking failures in this country in recent times. In my own State of South Australia the most recent State Bank catastrophe was in some respects similar to what happened the previous time South Australia lost a bank. The Bank of Adelaide was crippled 17 years ago in 1974 by its subsidiary Finance Corporation of Australia and had to be bought by the ANZ Bank. The big difference was that the limited number of voluntary shareholders in the Bank of Adelaide suffered in the former situation, whereas in the case of the State Bank all South Australians are compulsorily suffering because of the Bannon Labor Government's bale-out of the bank's enormous debt at taxpayers' expense.

This year in February the then newly appointed Chief Executive of the State Bank of South Australia, Stephen Patterson, claimed that there was no comparison between the State Bank disasters of Victoria and South Australia. He was right in one respect: the legacy that South Australian Labor Premier John Bannon has left South Australians is much worse than the legacy left to Victorians and Premier Joan Kirner by her Labor predecessor, John Cain. About the same proportion of their banks' loan books were not paying interest—17.1 per cent in South Australia and 19 per cent in Victoria—but the big difference between them was the location of the incompetence, and failure in South Australia to accept and distribute responsibility properly.

The common thread in Victoria and South Australia is that they arrived at exactly the same place, though it was by separate paths. Each State has had to sell assets to help raise $1 billion to pay for bad loans. Maybe Premier Bannon was exceptionally lucky in that he had some other assets to sell off. Premier Kirner was left an empty cupboard; she had to sell the bank itself. But, worse than that, Premier Bannon, through political expediency, indulged in the worst form of child abuse. He borrowed massively, thereby mortgaging to the hilt the future for South Australia's children to fund the bank's shortfall rather than having the guts to cop the fully deserved political fallout out of raising State taxes now to fund the debt. What unmitigated cowardice to make the next generation suffer for his folly and for the folly of this generation in ever entrusting him with the reins of government.

The intent of the Bill before us is essentially to facilitate the amalgamation of a savings bank subsidiary into its trading bank parent within those banking groups affected by the Government's decision to remove the distinction between trading and savings banks for regulatory purposes. It removes some significant impediments arising from the administration costs and legal difficulties associated with the integration of savings and trading banks within the same group.

As there will be no imposition of taxes and fees under State law and there will be neutrality under income tax law, the Bill has no financial impact and consequently the Liberal and National parties lend their support to it.

The history of bank regulation in this country has seen a strong distinction between trading banks and savings banks despite the fact that for much of the time even banks themselves saw that there was much to be gained from their amalgamation. But these very regulatory requirements placed unnecessary obstacles in the path of achieving the full economic benefits and efficiencies of a single bank focus. In 1989 the earlier Banking Legislation Amendment Act, as I have already mentioned, removed these regulatory distinctions between trading and savings banks, but left the legal entities still intact.

We are advised that this Bill is the result of extensive consultation with members of the Australian Bankers Association and it has the support of the banking industry. To that extent, in schedule 1 of the Bill's table of provisions, there are eight trading banks or receiving banks involved. These comprise the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, the Bank of New Zealand, the Bank of Queensland Ltd, Citibank Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the National Australia Bank Ltd, the National Mutual Royal Bank Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation. The transferring banks—that is, those which will be transferred across to the trading banks—will be the Australia and New Zealand Savings Bank Ltd, the Bank of New Zealand Savings Bank Ltd, the Bank of Queensland Savings Bank Ltd, Citibank Savings Ltd, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia, the National Australia Savings Bank Ltd, the National Mutual Royal Savings Bank Ltd and Westpac Savings Bank Ltd.

It is worth noting here that much of the credit for the evolution and initial development of banks—and, indeed, of the largest bank in Australia, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia—was provided not by a Labor Government, as is commonly believed, but in 1924 by an Act introduced by the Bruce-Page Nationalist-Country Party Government. Many of the progressive plans for the Bank's future were put in place by that Government.

Despite being the largest bank in Australia, the Commonwealth Bank, along with the National Australia and Westpac banks, has demonstrated a history of difficulties with bad debts. This is evident in, for example, the National Australia Bank Managing Director's review of 1989-90 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We were obliged to double the charge against profit for bad and doubtful debts while the cost of funding non-accrual loans became an increasing burden.

The Managing Director of Westpac and the annual report of the Commonwealth Bank make similar comments about bad debts. This was the case not only with the larger banks but also with, for example, the State owned Rural Industries Bank of Western Australia, the State Bank of New South Wales and the Tasmania Bank.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, none of this is news to the Opposition. These are precisely the sorts of problems we have been bringing to the fore for some time, but this hard of hearing Government chooses not to listen. It is no secret that the banking industry has undergone massive changes during the years of deregulation, but to blame deregulation for causing all bankers or customers ill is irresponsible in the extreme. However, during deregulation, banks and other financial organisations did not apply the correct risk control or accountability for many of their lending policies during the 1980s and that factor itself developed into a problem.

As a result of this poor risk control and poor loans policy by a number of our major banks, and together with their lack of accountability in that area, many bank customers overborrowed, became too highly geared and in a great majority of cases borrowed against assets already overvalued.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Government was good enough to table today a copy of the Summary Interim Report of the Australian Securities Commission into the administration of Burns Philp Trustee Co. Ltd as trustee of the Estate Mortgage Trusts. This matter is of particular importance because tomorrow in Sydney there is a meeting of unit holders of the six trusts administered by Burns Philp Trustee Co. as trustee for Estate Mortgage. There are some 52,000 Australians—mainly small investors—who put money into these trusts and who for almost the last 18 months have received nothing in return.

PARA.TAB: The report is significant in so much as I believe it is the first report by the Australian Securities Commission into mortgage trusts which are administered by trustee companies. At a time when Australians are increasingly being encouraged to provide for their own retirement it is significant that this Parliament and the Government ensure that there are correct and adequate procedures in place to oversee the management of these trusts. The report which has been tabled before the Senate clearly indicates the failure of the then existing regulatory regime. It also shows the clear failure of the National Companies and Securities Commission to properly oversee the trusts and the operations of the trustee.

I will not go into incredible length in discussing this matter, but I think it is appropriate to have a chronology of the relevant events, because in late 1989 there were a series of runs on Estate Mortgage and a number of adverse comments were made on the trusts by investment advisers. In early 1990 dividend distributions to unit holders were some two to three weeks late. Continued pressure on the liquidity of the trusts prompted the National Companies and Securities Commission on 16 February 1990 to require the trusts to produce cash flow reports every two days. At all times after 16 February 1990 redemptions exceeded new subscriptions to the trusts by at least $750,000 per day, with liquidity only being maintained by the borrowings and assignments of interests in mortgages held by the trusts. It is interesting to note that on some days it is believed that redemptions exceeded new subscriptions by as much as $7m—in the space of one day!

On 21 March 1990 supplemental trust deeds were executed, allowing the trustee to grant priority interests in assigned mortgages to third parties ahead of the trusts. These supplemental trust deeds required approval by the NCSC. The NCSC approved the supplemental trust deeds on 22 March 1990. Shortly thereafter a number of deeds of priority were executed in favour of certain banks and other financial institutions. On 30 March 1990 the trustee advised the NCSC that the trusts had failed to meet redemptions as required and further redemptions on units in the trust were frozen with the NCSC on 11 April 1990.

It is stated in the report by the Australian Securities Commission that it formed the view that there is evidence to suggest that Burns Philp Trustee Co. breached the terms of the trusts in the way it operated. The Commission formed this view because it believed there was evidence that breaches of trust had occurred when the trustee permitted the intermingling of unit holders' money between trusts. There were six different trusts and the moneys and the assets of at least five of these were all pooled, contrary to the terms of the trust. As a result, it has been almost impossible for the new trustees to ascertain which assets belong to which trust. The report has also found, and this is most significant:

SPEECH.PARA: Breaches of trust occurred when the Trustee authorised the execution of supplementary deeds providing for the assignment of mortgages and permitting the Trustee to fix the priority of the trusts ahead of, or behind, the assignee without considering, as set out in the trust deeds, whether unitholders may be adversely affected by such amendments.

The significance of that finding is very important. It means that when the trust was assigning interests in mortgages before 21 March, at best, the assignees ranked equal with the trusts. By giving them priority over the trusts, the trustee effectively diluted the net asset backing of the trusts and left the unit holders with nothing.

PARA.TAB: It was very clear as at 21 March that the value of the properties that constituted the trust portfolio had dropped dramatically. By giving a first ranking mortgage to a bank or another financial institution, the trustee effectively deprived the unit holders of the benefit of the value of those mortgages. For 52,000 Australians, as I am sure Senator Collins would agree, that is a very significant and very tragic finding.

The report of the Commission goes on to say that the trustee failed to require any procedures to regulate investments, despite the advice of lawyers to the contrary, and that breaches of trust occurred when the trustee purported to approve purchases of interests in mortgages when no documentation was executed to give effect to such purchases. The report is saying that the trustee purchased mortgages or mortgage interests in properties and never got adequate documentation. So potentially, the purchases could never be proved. That is frightening. We are talking about millions of dollars. The report also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Breaches of trust have occurred in relation to transactions in which companies associated with the Manager were involved and in which the Manager had a potential conflict of interest and the Trustee took no proper steps to obtain advice independent of the Manager.
That is particularly disturbing. The reasons why the ASC comes to that conclusion are contained in the body of the report, and I do not wish to canvass the matter further.

PARA.TAB: The Commission also finds that there is evidence that the trustee may have failed to exercise due diligence and vigilance in carrying out its functions. It sets out the reasons for that. That is very disturbing. People were putting their money into these trusts in the belief that they were investing in a safe investment; in fact, they found that was not the case. They found that the trusts were not even complying with the terms of the trust deed and, moreover, that the trust deeds were amended shortly before the trusts fell over, with a detrimental effect on unit holders.

There is another very important matter which is raised in the report. The supplemental trust deeds required the approval of the National Companies and Securities Commission. I believe that the NCSC acted negligently in allowing these trust deeds to be executed. It was under a duty to properly consider the interests of the trusts and unit holders when it approved the supplemental trust deeds on 22 March 1991. By approving these deeds, the NCSC facilitated the dilution of the net asset backing of the trusts when interests in mortgages were subsequently granted in priority to those of the trust. Although the supplemental trust deeds themselves did not result in a dilution of the net asset backing of the trusts, the consequent deeds of priority surely did. This surely should have been within the reckoning of the NCSC at the time it approved those deeds. There would have been no other purpose in creating those supplemental trust deeds other than to allow the trust to give priority to somebody else.

There is no way the NCSC could merely rely upon some assurance that the manager and the trustee were addressing the problem of declining liquidity in the trusts. The NCSC knew that from 16 February onwards there was a continuing drain on liquidity of the trusts. If it was sufficient for the NCSC to rely upon that assurance, there would have been little purpose in requiring the trust to make cash flow reports every two days. If it is to be said that the NCSC operated properly, it is necessary for the NCSC, or its successor, to show what steps it took to verify the assurances which were received.

Finally, the report makes recommendations as to deficiencies in the law which it believes need to be rectified. It says, in particular, that security properties being valued should not be valued on an on-completion basis, that the same valuers should not be used time and again to value properties in the same trust, and that failure by trustees to ensure that accounts in mortgage trusts disclose all matters which are likely to materially affect the prospects of the trusts should not be allowed.

In conclusion, the coalition will look very closely at these matters, as I am sure the Government will, because it is fundamental that we get these legislative provisions right. It was a very sad event that occurred. Everybody hopes that it does not occur again. This will only be done by properly looking into the activities in question. I look forward to hearing the deliberations of the Senate and the House of Representatives at a later date, as do all unit holders of these trusts, to ensure that this catastrophe never occurs again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the tactics—I suppose I would call them gutter tactics—that have been employed by this desperate Government, or the Government that is currently in its death throes, really have appalled me. One such tactic which I find particularly unacceptable and despicable is the growing tendency to use the needy as a political football. The shadow Minister for community services and aged care, Mr Ray Braithwaite, deserves to be congratulated because he has made an attempt to foster a bipartisan approach to matters relating to people with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, since the release of the Fightback program, Minister Richardson in particular has departed from this spirit of bipartisanship and has spuriously claimed that the coalition is looking to squeeze every last dollar and cent from the sick, the lame and the needy. Personally, I find that offensive, and I find it offensive to my colleagues as a whole. Nothing could be further from the truth. The coalition is about setting up active income support in which all beneficiaries, including people with disabilities, are given the opportunity and the incentives to become productive and financially self-sufficient members of our society.

This Government has been very keen to talk about social justice. It has become patently obvious that the political strategists have decided that social justice by default will be a major political theme for the Government in the run-up to the next election. How on earth the Government can decide on that when the level of unemployment is currently running at 10 per cent I do not know. But we should never be so naive that we take the Government's rhetoric at face value. After all, the proof of the pudding is in the eating. We should always ask whether the Government is backing up its self-congratulatory rhetoric with substantive programs.

One classic case that I have found which is all talk but very little positive action is the provision of Skillshare places for people with moderate disabilities. Under the now defunct community training program, the Government funded a limited number of specialist projects which provided training for people with disabilities. These projects were integrated into the newly formed Skillshare. In the 1991 Skillshare guidelines, special consideration was given to group focused projects which concentrated on the particular needs of people with disabilities. These projects received additional funding and special dispensation in terms of their contracted client numbers.

However, these group focused projects have been chopped from the 1992 Skillshare guidelines. The Government claims it has adopted a policy of integrating people with disabilities into all Skillshare projects and that it has set up disability access and support units to facilitate this integration. If it is anything like its integration of people into open employment, then I think it is already doomed. I have already pointed out to the chamber the figures and the appalling record that the Australian Public Service has in employing people with disabilities. Given that the Government is pushing towards closing down sheltered workshops and encouraging people with disabilities into open employment—a goal that we in the Opposition support; we did not support the way it was done—we would have expected the Australian Public Service to increase the number of people with disabilities, but that is not so. So where are these people supposed to go?

If the Government's record on integration is anything like the record it has already exhibited on integration of people with disabilities into the Australian Public Service, then I do not believe that what it is attempting to do here will be achieved, especially given some of the other facts I will put before the chamber.

The Government says that general outreach funding will be made available to offset the extra costs borne by individual Skillshare projects throughout this integration process. This sounds all very well and good, but it is important to look at the current participation rate of people with disabilities in Skillshare and the advice the Government has received from its own disability strategy consultancy. The participation rate of people with disabilities in Skillshare remains static at about 6 per cent, despite Minister Bolkus's claim last May that the rate was nearly 9 per cent. That is what he told us, but it is not what the figures show.

The latest statistics also reveal that 13.6 per cent of unemployed people awaiting placement have a disability, which is a 1.4 per cent increase on the figure that was cited by Minister Bolkus in May this year. Two points need to be made. First, people with disabilities are obviously very significantly underrepresented in Skillshare training programs; secondly, the degree of underrepresentation has not decreased and, in fact, appears to be increasing. This is a serious shortfall which obviously requires a substantive policy response from the Government. From the evidence to date, one doubts whether the Government's response has the substance that is required in this instance.

A consultancy comprising Dr John Lewis from the Phillip Institute of Technology and Ms Sandy Cook from the University of Melbourne was contracted to prepare a paper for the DEET Skillshare strategy. The draft of this paper was completed in July this year and distributed to all Skillshare projects. The paper made two very important recommendations. First, in recognition of significant assistance given to an increased number of clients with disabilities, individual Skillshare projects would be able to negotiate with area directors for a reduction in their contracted requirements in relation to the number of clients they would assist. The second important recommendation was that extra financial support, in the form of community outreach modular funding to individual projects, would be offered as a means of meeting any special needs of people with disabilities. Continued allocation of this modular funding would be dependent on projects meeting set target rates of participation by people with disabilities.

While the consultancy recommended that all generic Skillshare projects integrate people with disabilities, it recognised that there are additional costs inherent in catering for the special needs entailed in this integration process. Given that this draft strategy paper was distributed to all Skillshare projects, and given that the relevant section of the 1992 Skillshare guidelines, which are headed `Skillshare Disability Strategy', commences by saying, `A strategy for enhanced service delivery to people with disabilities has been developed for the Skillshare Program to ensure that this target group has equitable access to the Program', surely individual Skillshare projects could have felt confident that the recommendations from the strategy paper would be incorporated in the 1992 guidelines. However, this has not happened.

As I said earlier, the capacity for projects to provide services focused on people with disabilities has been removed from the guidelines, but there is no recognition in the guidelines of the fact that individual Skillshare projects may not be able to maintain a normal level of clients if they are to meet the targets that are set down in the strategy paper. This omission amounts to a major disincentive for Skillshare projects contemplating taking on larger numbers of people with disabilities.

The Skillshare strategy paper acknowledges the special training needs of people with disabilities. In many instances, meeting these special needs requires input of a larger number of manpower hours than would be the case for people without disabilities. Often, meeting the special needs of people with disabilities may also require the input of specialist trainers. Government funding of Skillshare projects is directly linked to client numbers. The Government's failure to take account of the special needs of people with disabilities by allowing a reduction in contracted client numbers, as I said before, will act as a significant disincentive to Skillshare projects taking on clients with disabilities.

There is also a major discrepancy between the draft strategy paper and the 1992 Skillshare guidelines in terms of the nature of community outreach funding that will be provided to Skillshare projects which actually do take on people with disabilities. The strategy paper sets out designated target rates of participation by people with disabilities as an incentive for the receipt of additional modular funding. These target rates are 8 per cent in 1992, 10 per cent in 1993 and 13 per cent in 1994. However, the Skillshare guidelines merely state:

SPEECH.PARA: Outreach funds may be used to enable generic SkillShare Sponsors to increase and improve services for people with disabilities.

These outreach funds are not restricted to projects which target people with disabilities. Outreach money for projects targeting people with disabilities will be taken from a pool of outreach funding which caters for rural and regional projects, as well as projects that cater for a range of other disadvantaged Skillshare target groups, such as disadvantaged youth. I am not saying that those groups should not be covered. What I am saying is that now those people with disabilities will have to compete with those groups for that outreach funding.

PARA.TAB: If the Government is really serious about achieving an across-the-board 13.6 per cent participation rate by people with disabilities in Skillshare, as Senator Bolkus claimed last week, then there must be real doubt as to whether there will be sufficient outreach funding to facilitate this increase—and it is a very significant increase—from the numbers who are now currently participating in Skillshare programs.

Given the fact that Skillshare and virtually every other DEET training program continues to be an abject failure in terms of recruiting numbers of people with disabilities that are comparable with their representation in the unemployed population, I am also very concerned that the designated target rates set out in the strategy paper have been omitted from the Skillshare guidelines. The 1992 guidelines merely state:

SPEECH.PARA: The actual percentage will be negotiated with Area Directors and will depend on the numbers of the particular category of the target groups in the local area and the degree of difficulty that may be experienced in encouraging participation.

During Question Time on 4 December I expressed these concerns to Minister Bolkus, who represents Mr Baldwin in the Senate. In his answer, the Minister stated that, to the extent that he had not answered my question, he would get further information for me. That is what he actually said. To assist Senator Bolkus, as I believed that he had not adequately answered my question, I wrote a letter to him the next day and expressed my concerns about the issues which I believed had not been addressed in the answer. I think he admitted in his answer to me, when he talked about any outstanding issues, that he believed that he had not adequately answered my question either.

PARA.TAB: I extended to him the courtesy of writing a letter and asking him to explain the discrepancy between the Skillshare guidelines and the strategy paper, and requesting confirmation that sufficient outreach money would be available to fund all Skillshare projects. No answer was forthcoming from the Minister, despite the fact that his office gave my office an undertaking that I would have an answer after Question Time on Monday. On Monday we had a delayed Question Time. I sat around waiting for Senator Bolkus's answer and, much to my surprise, he walked out of the chamber. I sat with eager anticipation on Tuesday, thinking that I would get an answer from Senator Bolkus. Again, he waltzed out of the chamber and I waited in vain.

I do not intend to wait in vain any longer and I believe I should bring this to the chamber. I asked the Minister a question, the question was not adequately answered, the Minister told me that he would get me further information and I have not got it. I consider that it is not adequate or appropriate for the Minister to behave in that way.

Today Senator Bolkus's office informed my office that no answer would be provided until the Minister met with the peak organisation—namely ACROD—in a week's time. We most probably will not be here then. I consider the behaviour of Mr Baldwin and Senator Bolkus, representing Mr Baldwin, to be a disgraceful

SPEECH.PARA: disregard of this House. I asked the Minister a question in relation to a program which is funded from the 1991-92 Budget and about which 1992 guidelines have been drawn up and given to program providers. My question was a simple one: there was a discrepancy and I wanted to know why. My question was one which had the potential to impact on a significant number of people with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: I am fully aware that ACROD has expressed its concerns to the Minister in relation to this matter. But the Minister simply refused to answer my question until he was able to sort it out in some way. It should be as plain as the nose on his face. He should be able to say why there is a difference and, if there is a difference, whether it was an error or whether it was intentional and the Government does not intend to fund that integration which it boasts about. I believe the Minister's behaviour amounts to nothing less than a dismissing of the role of the Senate as a representative of the people and, particularly in this instance, as a representative of those people with disabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the representative of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) advised and/or briefed the Minister on the Board's decision to invest $1.2 million in a private company which proposes a straw pulp mill at Moora, Western Australia.

(2) Did the AWB's decision to invest in this company require and receive Ministerial approval; if so, was the Minister provided with a copy of a report of a study into the project by the internationally recognised expert consultants Jaakko Poyry, which was commissioned by the AWB.
(3) Is it true that Jaakko Poyry recommended against the investment.

(4) Is it true that another, equally internationally recognised, expert consultant group NLK CELPAP of Sweden has also undertaken a study of the Moora straw pulp mill proposal and firmly stated that the project was not commercial viable.

(5) Did the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, whose members would be affected by this proposal, commission Professor Hicks, Acting Head of the School of Banking and Finance at Monash University to undertake a learned review of the proposal and did Professor Hicks study also conclude that the project was not commercially viable.
(6) Will the Minister make copies of the Jaakko Poyry report available to Honourable Senators.
(7) In light of all the expert opinion recommending against the project, will the Minister advise the AWB to withdraw their investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was briefed by his Department on a request from the AWB for approval to acquire shares in the Moora Pulp and Paper Co. Pty. Ltd. (the Company). The Secretary of the Department, who at the time was the Government Member on the Board of the AWB, was provided with a copy of that briefing.

(2) The AWB wrote to the Minister on 6 June 1991 seeking his approval for this investment. On the basis of advice from Attorney-General's Department, the AWB was informed by the Minister that it did not require Ministerial approval to invest money of the Wheat Industry Fund (WIF) in this project, provided the AWB was assured that the purpose of the acquisition of the shares was for the sake of the income to be generated by the investment and not for some other purpose. Ministerial approval had previously been given under Section 82(1)(e) of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 for the AWB to invest WIF money in any manner consistent with sound commercial practice. In their request for approval the AWB did not advise the Minister of the existence of any consultant's reports into the project, either by Jaakko Poyry or any other consultant group. The Minister was advised by the AWB that the Grains Council of Australia had approved the project and the use of WIF moneys to finance the acquisition.

(3), (4), (5) and (6) Subsequent to the AWB going ahead with its proposal, the Minister became aware that Jaakko Poyry had provided to the AWB a confidential report on the project which was also made available to the Moora Board. The report remains confidential and for this reason was not provided to the Minister and is therefore not available to the Parliament. The assessment of the findings of that report was a matter of commercial judgement for the AWB. The results of other studies on the Moora project which were commissioned by outside organisations, such as the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, remain confidential to those persons unless they have agreed to release them. Even in that case, it would not be appropriate for the Minister to comment, since such findings need to be evaluated against other commercial information in respect of the project which would not normally be readily available.

(7) The Wheat Marketing Act 1989 and the associated Wheat Industry Fund Regulations set out in broad terms the purposes for which WIF monies may be used. The legislation also requires the AWB to manage the WIF in accordance with an Annual Business Plan approved by the Grains Council of Australia. The Minister is not involved in the development or approval of these Plans and this arrangement recognises that the WIF is an industry fund made up from a levy on wheat growers. The Government's main involvement with the WIF is the provision of a five year $100m guarantee for WIF related borrowings, which in the first instance are backed by the WIF and its associated assets. Given that the interim report of the WIF for the 12 months to 30 June 1991 indicated a value of over $70m, the first stage of the Moora investment, at only $1.2m, is a small fraction of the equity in the WIF. In this case there are no grounds for the Minister to intervene.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: For what length of time or number of parliaments must a Senator serve to qualify for a Parliamentary pension if the Senator retires (a) voluntarily, or (b) involuntarily.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Parliamentary retiring allowances (parliamentary pensions) are provided to former Members of Parliament in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948.
On retirement from the Parliament, a Senator is entitled to a parliamentary retiring allowance if:

(a) on voluntary retirement, 12 years service has been completed, or the Senator has ceased to be a Senator on 4 occasions on the dissolution or expiration of the Senate or on the expiration of a term as a Senator;

(b) on involuntary retirement, 8 years service has been completed, or the Senator has ceased to be a Senator on 3 occasions on the dissolution or expiration of the Senate or on the expiration of a term as a Senator.

For the purpose of reckoning `occasions', a Senator whose term of office was 6 years is regarded as having an `occasion' after the completion of 3 years of that 6 year term, in addition to an occasion on the expiration of that 6 year term.

A Senator may also be entitled to a retiring allowance before completing 8 years service or 3 `occasions' if the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust is satisfied that the Senator's retirement from the Parliament is due to ill-health.
